revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = A9.com, Inc. | logo = | type = Search Engine | foundation = | location = [[Palo Alto]], [[California]] | key_people = | industry = Communications | products = | revenue = | image = Image:ph-landscapes-dec-src-1.jpg | image_caption = A9.com office in Palo Alto, CA | num_employees = | parent = [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] | homepage = {{Url |a9.com}} }}
'''A9.com''' is a [[subsidiary]] of [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] that develops [[search engine technology|search engine]] and [[search advertising]] technology. A9 is based in [[Palo Alto, California]], with teams in [[Bangalore]], [[Beijing]], [[Dublin]], [[Iași]], [[Munich]] and [[Tokyo]]. A9 has development efforts in areas of product search, cloud search, visual search, augmented reality, advertising technology and community question answering.
==History==
A9 was created by Amazon.com in 2003 as an independent company aimed at producing technology for search and advertising. They moved into the building previously used by the [[DEC Systems Research Center]] in [[Palo Alto, California]]. One purpose of A9.com was to leverage [[algorithm]]s, and the name was chosen as a [[numeronym]] to represent that word (i.e. 'A' + 9 other letters). The office was in [[Silicon Valley]], near [[Stanford University]].<ref name="udi04">{{Cite news|title=Can Amazon Unplug Google? |work=Business 2.0 |author=John Battelle |date=April 15, 2004 |url=http://www.business2.com/b2/web/articles/0,17863,611251,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040416090804/http://www.business2.com/b2/web/articles/0%2C17863%2C611251%2C00.html |archivedate=April 16, 2004 |accessdate=November 15, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Under the direction of its first president, [[Udi Manber]], A9 focused on several areas, including the A9.com destination website, product search, and a search advertising platform. Some early A9 services such as "search inside the book" continued, while others have been discontinued. The A9 search engine powers product search for Amazon.com and several other eCommerce retailers.
In February 2006, Manber was replaced by [[David L. Tennenhouse]] as president.<ref name="post">{{cite web |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/08/AR2006020802243.html |title= Google Hires Amazon Executive |date= February 9, 2006 |work= [[The Washington Post]] |accessdate= November 20, 2016 }}</ref> In September 2006, William Stasior, one of A9's founders and a former [[AltaVista]] and Amazon.com executive, was named president. In June 2009, A9 acquired SnapTell, which developed smartphone-based visual search applications.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Image Recognition Startup SnapTell Acquired by Amazon Subsidiary A9.com |author= Leena Rao |date= June 16, 2009 |work= Tech Crunch |url= https://techcrunch.com/2009/06/16/image-recognition-startup-snaptell-acquired-by-amazon-subsidiary-a9com/ |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref>
Stasior left in October 2012 to join [[Apple Inc.]] and work on [[Siri]].<ref>{{Cite news |title= Apple Nabs Amazon A9 Exec Stasior to Run Siri — But Does Hire Signal a Bigger Move Into Search? |date= October 15, 2012 |author= Kara Swisher |work= All Things D |url= http://allthingsd.com/20121015/exclusive-apple-hires-amazon-a9s-stasior-to-run-siri-does-hire-signal-a-bigger-move-into-search/ |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref> Brian Pinkerton, who had developed [[WebCrawler]] in the 1990s, became general manager of A9 in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Leading Leaders |work= A9 Management web page |url= https://www.a9.com/about-us/management/ |archivedate= November 14, 2016 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20161114072240/https://www.a9.com/about-us/management/ |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title= Search engines we have known ... before Google crushed them |author= Brid-Aine Parnell |date= December 18, 2012 |work= The Register |url= https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/12/18/search_engines_we_have_known/?page=3 |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref>
==Past projects==
===A9.com search portal===
A9.com originally operated a [[web portal|search portal]], along with an A9 [[toolbar]], which was first demonstrated on April 14, 2004.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Amazon's Much Discussed a9 Goes Live |date= April 14, 2004 |author= Gary Price |work= Resource Shelf |url= http://www.resourceshelf.com/archives/2004_04_01_resourceshelf_archive.html#108196836452740143 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20040416222616/http://www.resourceshelf.com/archives/2004_04_01_resourceshelf_archive.html#10819683645274014 |archivedate= April 16, 2004 |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref> The service featured some innovative design elements, allowing users to choose from over 400 sources to search and view results in separate columns grouped by source. In addition to web search results, users could get product search results from Amazon, encyclopedia results from [[Wikipedia]], movie information from [[IMDb]], and others, starting in September 2004.<ref>{{Cite news |title= Amazon to Take Searches On Web to a New Depth |author= [[John Markoff]] |work= New York Times |date= September 15, 2004 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/15/business/technology/technology-amazon-to-take-searches-on-web-to-a-new.html |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref> Web search results were provided by different search engines over time. The search portal functionality was discontinued in 2008.
===Open Search===
A9 developed a protocol called [[OpenSearch]] that enabled the "plug-in" search source functionality from the A9.com portal. The original specification, OpenSearch 1.0, was released in March 2005. A9 made the protocol freely available through a [[Creative Commons]] license. OpenSearch is now{{When|date=November 2016}} maintained by the OpenSearch.org community.
===BlockView===
A9 developed the first service that allowed users of maps and "[[yellow pages]]" (a [[telephone directory]]) to view buildings at street level. Called BlockView, the service was announced in January 2005.<ref>{{Cite web |author= Kurt Peters |title= Yellow Pages Go Visual with Block View at Amazon's A9.com |work= Internet Retailer |date= January 27, 2005 |url= http://www.internetretailer.com/2005/01/27/yellow-pages-go-visual-with-block-view-at-amazon-s-a9-com |accessdate= November 19, 2016 }}</ref> Within a year, the service included images for 24 US cities. Both BlockView and maps (as well as support for the A9 tool bar) were discontinued in September 2006.<ref>{{Cite web |title= So Long to A9's Block Level Imagery, Yellow Pages, Tollbar and Amazon.com Discount |work= Resource Shelf |date= October 1, 2006 |url= http://www.resourceshelf.com/2006/10/01/search-briefs-a9-discontinues-many-features-yahoo-to-open-yahoo-mail-api/ |archivedate= October 5, 2006 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061005033120/http://www.resourceshelf.com/2006/10/01/search-briefs-a9-discontinues-many-features-yahoo-to-open-yahoo-mail-api/ |accessdate= November 19, 2016 }}</ref>
===Clickriver===
In November 2006, A9 announced Clickriver, an advertising program that let third parties place advertisements on Amazon.com pages.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Amazon.com's Clickriver Pay-Per-Click Search Advertising |author= Loren Baker |work= Search Engine Journal |date= November 3, 2006 |url= https://www.searchenginejournal.com/amazoncoms-clickriver-ppc-to-bypass-google-adwords/3972/ |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref> Clickriver focused primarily on products and services that complemented Amazon's own offerings. For example, if a customer viewed a television on Amazon, a Clickriver ad might offer installation services in his or her local area. Clickriver was discontinued in 2010, replaced by other Amazon advertising programs.
=== Community question answering === A9 operated [[Askville]], a community-based [[question-and-answer site]] first tested in December 2006. Service began in November 2007.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Aarthi Sivaraman |date= November 29, 2007 |publisher= Reuters |title= Amazon Launches Askville.com |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/11/29/us-amazon-askville-idUSWNAS341420071129 |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref> Compared with other question-and-answer sites, Askville focused more on social interaction, allowing users to follow other users as well as track specific topics. On October 25, 2013, Askville was shut down.<ref>{{Cite web |title= Dear Askville Community |work= Final web site |url= http://www.askville.com/ |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140110015731/http://www.askville.com/ |archivedate= January 10, 2014 |accessdate= November 15, 2016 }}</ref>
===Cloud search=== CloudSearch is a managed [[Amazon Web Services]] service that makes client data searchable.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Timothy Prickett Morgan |title= Amazon Turns A9 Search Engine into a Cloud Service |work= The Register |date= April 12, 2012 |url= https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/04/12/amazon_aws_cloudsearch |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref> For example, a business that wanted to allow customers to search their catalog could upload the catalog entries to CloudSearch and then route search requests from their application or web site to the service. CloudSearch instances could be brought online as data or traffic volume demanded. Sites using CloudSearch included [[SmugMug]],<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://news.smugmug.com/2012/04/12/smugmugs-sexy-new-search/ |title= SmugMug's Sexy New Search |work= SmugMug Blog |date= April 12, 2012 |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref> and [[Sage Bionetworks]].<ref>{{cite web|title=On the Shoulders of Giants |date=April 12, 2012 |author=Michael Kellen |work=Science, Reengineered blog |url=http://sciencereengineered.com/2012/04/14/on-the-shoulders-of-giants/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427153704/http://sciencereengineered.com/2012/04/14/on-the-shoulders-of-giants/ |archivedate=April 27, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
In March 2014, Amazon moved away from using A9 for CloudSearch to technology based on [[Apache Solr]].<ref>{{Cite web |title= Amazon CloudSearch - Even Better Searching for Less Than $100/Month |work= Amazon Web Service blog |author= Jeff Barr |date= March 24, 2014 |url= http://aws.typepad.com/aws/2014/03/amazon-cloudsearch-even-better-searching-for-less-than-100month.html }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title= Amazon’s CloudSearch gets Solr Powered! |work= Lucidworks blog |date= March 25, 2014 |url= https://lucidworks.com/blog/2014/03/25/amazons-cloudsearch-gets-solr-powered/ }}</ref>
==Recent projects==
===Product search=== A9 continued to develop and operate the service that provides search on all nine Amazon.com sites, as well as other retail sites owned by Amazon such as [[Endless.com]], Javari.de, and [[Audible.com]]. In addition, A9 search is also used by other retailers, such as [[Marks & Spencer]],<ref>"Marks & Spencer Launches Website in Collaboration with Amazon," ''Computer Weekly,'' March 23, 2007. [http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240080492/Marks-Spencer-launches-website-in-collaboration-with-Amazon]</ref> that license the Amazon retail platform for their online presence.
A9 provided the "search inside the book" capability for Amazon.<ref>Gary Price, "Amazon Debuts New Book Search Tool," ''Search Engine Watch,'' October 26, 2003 [http://searchenginewatch.com/article/2064555/Amazon-Debuts-New-Book-Search-Tool]</ref> Announced in 2003, this service allows customers to search through the full text of hundreds of thousands of books. This feature is available both for searching individual books and for the entire book catalog. <ref>{{Cite news |title= Welcome to History 2.0 |work= Newsweek by the Daily Beast |author= Steven Levy |date= November 9, 2003 |url= http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2003/11/09/welcome-to-history-2-0.html |deadurl= yes |archivedate= May 6, 2012 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120506145828/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2003/11/09/welcome-to-history-2-0.html |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref>
===Visual search===
The visual search group at A9 created mobile applications that recognize objects and allow users to find these products on Amazon.com. Their first augmented reality app, Flow, provided both object and barcode recognition. It was released in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web |author= Will Shanklin |title= Flow for iPhone is the product ID App We Have Been Waiting For |work= Geek.com |date= November 3, 2011 |url= http://www.geek.com/articles/mobile/flow-for-iphone-is-the-product-id-app-we-have-been-waiting-for-2011113 |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title= Flow iPhone app |work= iTunes |url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/flow-powered-by-amazon/id474664425 |accessdate= November 17, 2016 }}</ref>
A9 visual search technology powers features to let customers search for certain products (such as shoes) by shape, and find visually similar items on Amazon.com, [[Zappos.com]], Endless.com, and other retail sites.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}}
===Advertising technology===
A9's advertising technology group began delivering sponsored link advertisements on the Amazon.com retail Web site in 2003 and continued to manage this program for Amazon properties. A9 also invests in display advertising technology, including technology for Amazon's ad-supported e-reader, the [[Amazon Kindle|Kindle]] with special offers.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}}
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Amazon}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:A9.Com}} [[Category:Internet search engines]] [[Category:Amazon (company)]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2004]] [[Category:Web mapping]]<!-- for BlockView --> [[Category:Creative Commons-licensed authors]]

In 1991, [[Azerbaijan]] joined the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|OIC]] and started to build relations with the organization. As a result, the ambassador of Azerbaijan to [[Saudi Arabia]] was given a mandate of permanent representative of Azerbaijan to the General Secretariat of the OIC in May 1994.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.az/en/content/550|title=AZERBAIJAN AND OIC|last=FS|website=www.mfa.gov.az|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
== Cooperation == A former Azerbaijani President [[Heydar Aliyev]] met with the OIC Secretary General in [[Baku]] in 1994. Furthermore, Heydar Aliyev attended the 7th Summit of Heads of States and Governments of the OIC member countries in Casablanca and made a speech in that year.<ref name=":0" />
In 2005, current Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev attended the 3rd Extraordinary Summit of the OIC in Mecca. In 2015, President Aliyev met with the Secretary General of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), [[Iyad bin Amin Madani|Iyad Ameen Madan]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic/?t_id=9953&ref=3944&lan=en|title=OIC Secretary General receives the President of Azerba...|website=www.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
Baku hosted the 33rd OIC Foreign Ministers Conference in 19–21 June 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.oic-oci.org/baku2006/english/documents.htm|title=The Thirty-Third Session of The Islamic Conference of Foreign Ministers|website=ww1.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref> Additionally, [[Mehriban Aliyeva]], the President of [[Heydar Aliyev Foundation]] initiated to organize International Forum on “Expanding the Role of Women in Cross-Cultural Dialogue” in Baku on June 10–11, 2008.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic/?t_id=13550&ref=5905&lan=en|title=The 4th Islamic Solidarity Games Officially Opens in B...|website=www.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
The delegation led by [[Elmar Mammadyarov]], Azerbaijani FM regularly participates at the OIC Foreign Ministers conferences.
On 22–23 November 2011, the Islamic Conference Youth Forum for Dialogue and Cooperation (ICYF-DC), Heydar Aliyev Foundation and Azerbaijani Government organized the Founding Convention of the OIC Countries Young Entrepreneurs Network in Baku. ICYEN is a collaborative initiative to create a platform for young Muslim entrepreneurs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.icyf-dc.org/icyen-was-established-in-baku-2/|title=ICYEN WAS ESTABLISHED IN BAKU|date=2011-11-25|work=Islamic Conference Youth Forum for Dialogue and Cooperation|access-date=2017-09-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2017, the 4th [[Islamic Solidarity Games]] was held in Azerbaijan. An official opening ceremony was organized in Baku on May 12, 2017.<ref name=":1" />
Furthermore, Azerbaijan has achieved cooperation with other bodies of the OIC. In this regard, Azerbaijan’s First Lady and also head of the Heydar Aliyev Foundation Mehriban Aliyeva’s activities must be noted which contributed to the development of ties between Azerbaijan and the OIC. Therefore, Aliyeva was awarded with the diploma on [[Goodwill ambassador|Goodwill Ambassador]] of the [[Islamic Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|ISESCO]] by the Director General of the ISESCO Dr. Abdulaziz Othman Altwaijri for her deeds to bring civilizations closer in 26 November 2006 . Moreover, Prof. Dr. Ekmeleddin Ihsanoghlu awarded her with the diploma on [[Diplomatic rank|Special Envoy]] of the OIC on [[Humanitarianism|Humanitarian]] Affairs for her activity in the humanitarian field while attending the International Forum on “Expanding the Role of Women in Cross-Cultural Dialogue” which was held in Baku in 10–11 June 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic/?t_id=1147&ref=533&lan=en|title=OIC Chief expounds views on role of women in cross cul...|website=www.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
On 3 May 2017, a delegation led by Secretary General of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) [[Yousef Al-Othaimeen]] met with Azerbaijani President [[Ilham Aliyev]]. The meeting involved the discussions over the solidarity and cooperation between [[Muslim]] countries, Azerbaijan’s successful membership to the OIC and tourism potentials.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.president.az/mobile/articles/23501|title=President.Az -|website=en.president.az|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
== The OIC and Armenia-Azerbaijan Nagorno-Karabakh conflict == [[Armenia]]-Azerbaijan, [[Nagorno-Karabakh conflict]] became one of the topic for discussions since Azerbaijan had been admitted to the membership of the OIC . The OIC adopted a number of resolutions regarding the conflict condemning the occupation of the Azerbaijani territories by Armenia:
1.Final Communique of the 7th Session of The Islamic Summit Conference [[Casablanca]], [[Morocco|Kingdom of Morocco]] (13-15 December 1994) .<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.oic-oci.org/english/conf/is/7/7th-is-summit.htm#FINAL%20COMMUNIQUE|title=7th Islamic Summit|website=ww1.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
2. Final Communique of the 8th Session of The Islamic Summit Conference [[Tehran]], [[Iran|Islamic Republic of Iran]] (9-11 December 1997)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.oic-oci.org/english/conf/is/8/8th-is-summits.htm#final|title=8th Islamic Summit|website=ww1.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
3. Final Communique of the 9th Session of The Islamic Summit Conference [[Doha]], [[Qatar|State of Qatar]] (12-13 November 2000)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.oic-oci.org/english/conf/is/9/9th-is-sum-final_communique.htm#fc|title=FINAL COMMUNIQUE|website=ww1.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
4. “Resolution no. 25/9-c (is) on the destruction and desecration of islamic historical and cultural relics and shrines in the occupied Azeri territories resulting from the republic of Armenia's aggression against the Republic of Azerbaijan”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.oic-oci.org/english/conf/is/9/9th-is-sum-cultural.htm#25|title=RESOLUTIONS|website=ww1.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
5. “Resolution No.21/9-P(IS) on the aggression of the Republic of Armenia against the Republic of Azerbaijan”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww1.oic-oci.org/english/conf/is/9/9th-is-sum-political_2.htm#21|title=RESOLUTION NO|website=ww1.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
Documents and resolutions on Armenia-Azerbaijan, Nagorno-Karabakh conflict were approved at the OIC Foreign Ministers conferences, too. For instance, resolution No. 10/42-POL “On the Aggression of the Republic of Armenia against the Republic of Azerbaijan” adopted in the framework of the Forty Second Session of the Council of Foreign Ministers, held in [[Kuwait]], State of Kuwait on 27–28 May 2015. The resolution strongly condemns Armenian aggression against Azerbaijan, considers the actions committed by the Armenian Armed Forces against the Azerbaijani civilians and other protected persons as crimes against humanity and calls the [[United Nations Security Council|UN Security Council]] to recognize the existence of aggression against Azerbaijan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/subweb/cfm/42/en/42cfm_res_pol_r2_en.pdf|title=Resolutions On Political Affairs Adopted by the 42nd Session of the Council of Foreign Ministers Session of Joint Vision to Strengthen Tolerance and Reject Terrorism|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
OIC Secretary General regularly commemorates the [[Khojaly Massacre|Khojaly Genocide]] committed by [[Armed Forces of Armenia|Armenian Armed Forces]] against Azerbaijani civilians in February 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oic-oci.org/topic/?t_id=13169&ref=5769&lan=en|title=OIC Secretary General commemorates Khojaly Massacre...|website=www.oic-oci.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref> In 2017, Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) Secretary-General [[Yousef Al-Othaimeen|Yousef al-Othaimeen]] called for the "immediate" and "unconditional" withdrawal of the Armenian Armed Forces from occupied Azerbaijani territories while marking the 25th anniversary of the 1992 Khojaly Genocide.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailysabah.com/europe/2017/03/14/oic-urges-armenia-to-evacuate-azerbaijani-land-it-occupies|title=OIC urges Armenia to evacuate Azerbaijani land it occupies|work=DailySabah|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref>
== See also == [http://www.mfa.gov.az/en/content/550 Azerbaijan and OIC]
[http://mfa.gov.az/en/content/841 OIC]

{{Infobox airport | name = Barreira do Inferno Launch Center | nativename = ''Centro de Lançamento da Barreira do Infern''o | image = Barreira do Inferno.jpg | image2 = RioGrandedoNorte Municip Parnamirim.svg | caption2 = Location in Rio Grande do Norte | IATA = | ICAO = | type = [[Military base]]
[[Spaceport]] | operator = [[Brazilian Air Force]]
[[Brazilian Space Agency]] | location = [[Parnamirim]], [[Rio Grande do Norte]], [[Brazil]] | built = 1965 | used = 1965 - present | commander = | occupants = | elevation-f = | elevation-m = | coordinates = {{coord|05|55|30|S|035|09|47|W|region:BR_type:airport|display=it}} | website = [http://www.clbi.cta.br/ www.clbi.cta.br] | r1-number = | r1-length-f = | r1-length-m = | r1-surface = | footnotes = }} [[File:Barreira do Inferno Launch Center, Parnamirim, Brazil.jpg|thumb|left|Center for Spatial Culture and Tourist Information at the Barreira do Inferno Launch Center]] The '''Barreira do Inferno Launch Center''' ({{lang-pt|Centro de Lançamento da Barreira do Inferno; '''CLBI''', trans. "Hell's Barrier"}}) is a [[Spaceport|rocket launch base]] of the [[Brazilian Space Agency]]. It was created in 1965,[http://www.clbi.cta.br/new/variados.php?tp=missao Centro De Lançamento Da Barreira Do Iinferno] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904070404/http://www.clbi.cta.br/new/variados.php?tp=missao |date=September 4, 2013 }} and is located in the city of [[Parnamirim]], near [[Natal, Rio Grande do Norte|Natal]], the capital of the state of [[Rio Grande do Norte]]. It has been used for 233 launches from 1965 to 2007, reaching up to 1100 kilometers altitude. It provides [[Radar tracker|tracking]] support for launches from the [[Alcântara Launch Center]] and [[Guiana Space Centre]]. ==Launches== [[File:Lançamento do foguete Black Brandt, na Barreira do Inferno (RN).tif|thumb|right| Launch of the [[Black Brant (rocket)|Black Brandt rocket]] in 1973]] Several rockets where launched from CLBI:[http://www.astronautix.com/sites/natal.htm Natal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031031075958/http://astronautix.com/sites/natal.htm |date=2003-10-31 }} *[[Loki-Dart Sounding Rocket|Loki-Dart]] *[[Nike-Cajun]] *[[Project Orion (nuclear propulsion)|Orion-OLV]] *[[Nike-Apache]] *[[Aerobee 150]] *[[Javelin (rocket)|Javelin]] *[[Nike-Tomahawk]] *[[Black Brant (rocket)#Black Brant IV|Black Brant 4A]] *[[Nike-Iroquois]] *[[Boosted Dart]] *[[ARCAS#Super Arcas|Super Arcas]] *[[Rocketsonde]] *[[Black Brant (rocket)#Black Brant V|Black Brant 5C]] *[[Black Brant (rocket)#Black Brant IV|Black Brant 4B]] *[[Paiute Tomahawk]] *[[Castor Lance]] *[[Black Brant (rocket)#Black Brant VIII|Black Brant 8B]] *[[Sonda 3]] *[[Skylark (rocket)|Skylark 12]] *[[Cuckoo 4]] *[[Nike Orion]] *[[Sonda 4]] *[[VLS-1#VLS-R1 test vehicle|VLS-R1]] *[[VS-30]] ===Projected=== *''Operação São Lourenço'' - [[VS-40]]/[[Satélite de Reentrada Atmosférica|SARA]] Suborbital I ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.clbi.cta.br/ Official site]

page.title: Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.4.1)
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=October 2013}} [[File:Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World.jpg|thumb|''Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World'']] The '''''Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World''''' is a large-format English language atlas of ancient [[Europe]], [[Asia]], and North [[Africa]], edited by [[Richard Talbert|Richard J. A. Talbert]]. The time period depicted is roughly from [[Archaic Greece|archaic Greek]] civilization (pre-550 BC) through [[Late Antiquity]] (640 AD). The atlas was published by [[Princeton University Press]] in 2000. The book was the winner of the 2000 [[Association of American Publishers]] [[PROSE Awards|Award for Best Professional/Scholarly Multivolume Reference Work in the Humanities]].
==Overview== The main (atlas) volume contains 102 color topographic maps, covering territory from the [[British Isles]] and the [[Azores]] and eastward to [[Afghanistan]] and western [[China]]. The size of the volume is 33 x 48 cm. A 45-page [[gazetteer]] is also included in the atlas volume. The atlas is accompanied by a map-by-map directory on CD-ROM, in [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] format, including a search index. The map-by-map directory is also available in print as a two-volume, 1,500 page edition.
According to the editor, the purpose of each map is to offer an up-to-date presentation of the important physical and covered features of the area, using all available literal, epigraphic, and archaeological data.
Most of the maps are of the scale 1:1,000,000 or 1:500,000. However, the environs of the three greater centers ([[Athens]], [[Rome]], [[Byzantium]]-[[Constantinople]]) are presented in 1:150,000. Some remote regions, where Greeks and Romans mostly explored and traded rather than settled (i.e. [[Baltic region|Baltic]], [[Arabia]], [[East Africa]], [[India]], [[Sri Lanka]]), are of the scale 1:5,000,000. Due to the nature of the base maps used for the background and time–cost restrictions, elevation lines (contours) were left in feet except for the 1:150,000 maps where they are in meters. The [[Map projection|projection]] of the maps is [[Lambert conformal conic projection|Lambert Conformal Conic]]. Again due to time and cost restrictions, [[Georeference|geo-referencing]] of the maps was left as a future separate project.
Effort was spent to show the physical landscape in its ancient rather than modern aspect. As expected, this task often met insurmountable difficulties, due to the lack of data. In those cases, at least an effort was made to eliminate known modern features and to restore the affected landscapes.
The atlas' production began in 1988 at the [[University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill]], and involved a team of 221 classicists and 22 map makers.<ref name=NYTBR>{{cite news|author=[[D. J. R. Bruckner]]|date=March 4, 2001|title=Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/03/04/books/books-in-brief-nonfiction-052841.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times Book Review]]|page=22}}</ref> The effort was funded by $4.5 million—"an unusually large sum for a project in the humanities"<ref name=NYT-Wilford>{{cite news|author=[[John Noble Wilford]]|date=December 12, 2000|title=An Atlas Unveils the Intricacies of Ancient Worlds|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/12/science/an-atlas-unveils-the-intricacies-of-ancient-worlds.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|page=D5}}</ref>—in federal and private donations. The largest individual contributor was Robert B. Strassler's family philanthropy ''The Barrington Foundation'' which supported the project with over $1 million and for which, in accordance with the donor's wishes, the atlas is named. (The foundation, in turn, is named after the Strassler family's place of residence, [[Great Barrington, Massachusetts]].)<ref name=APAN>{{cite news|author=Richard Talbert|date=October 1999|title=Classical Atlas Project|url=https://classicalstudies.org/sites/default/files/documents/newsletters/October_1999.pdf#page=4|newspaper=[[American Philological Association]] [[Newsletter]]|pages=2–4|volume=22|issue=5}}</ref>{{rp|4}}<ref>{{cite journal|author=Richard J. A. Talbert|title= Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World: the Cartographic Fundamentals in Retrospect|url=http://www.cartographicperspectives.org/index.php/journal/article/view/cp46-talbert/539|journal=[[Cartographic Perspectives]]|issue=46|pages=4–27|doi=10.14714/CP46.484|year=Fall 2003|format=PDF}}</ref>{{rp|23}}
The atlas provides an up-to-date reference for ancient geography, superseding [[William Smith (lexicographer)|William Smith]]'s ''An Atlas of Ancient Geography, Biblical and Classical'' (London: John Murray, 1872–1874), the last successfully completed attempt to comprehensively map the [[Greco-Roman world]] and reflect the state of scholarship.<ref>Cf. {{cite journal|author=Richard J. A. Talbert|title=Mapping the classical world: major atlases and map series 1872-1990|url=http://www.journalofromanarch.com/v5_thum_page.html|journal=[[Journal of Roman Archaeology]]|volume=5|pages=5–38|doi=10.1017/S1047759400011922|year=1992}}</ref>
An ongoing wiki-like on-line large scale collaboration for maintaining and diversifying the ''Barrington Atlas'' data-set is carried on by the Pleiades Project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pleiades.stoa.org |title=pleiades.stoa.org |website=Pleiades.stoa.org |date= |accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref>
==Period coverage== The time period covered is roughly from 1000 BC up to c. AD 640, categorized as following: *[[Archaic period in Greece|Archaic period]] (pre-550 BC] *[[Classical antiquity|Classical period]] (550–330 BC) *[[Hellenistic period]] / [[Roman Republic#Mid-Republic (264–133 BC)|Middle to Late Republican period]] at Rome (330 BC–30 BC) *[[Principate|Early Roman Empire]] (30 BC–AD 300) *[[Late Antiquity]] (300–640) All eras are covered in every map (i.e. there are not separate maps for different periods of the same region).
==Naming conventions== The Latin titles given to the regional categories and to the individual maps (see below) are no more than generalized identifications. E.g. Internum Mare (literally, "Internal Sea") is the region around Mediterranean Sea.
Inside maps, ancient names are underlined with specific colors, when they are applicable only to a specific era. Where modern names are used, they are printed in different (sans-serif) font. For the physical features, standard Latin descriptive terms are usually used (e.g. Lacus for Lake, Mons for Mountain). Explanations for these terms are given in the Map Key. When there is doubt whether the name correctly applies to a feature or area, it is followed by a question mark. When only the approximate location is known, the name is italicized.
==Atlas volume contents== *Contributors, Reviewers, Cartographers *Preface, Introduction, Guidelines for Reference *[[MapQuest]] Production Data, Map Bases *Six small-scale overview maps at 1:5,000,000: **Map Key, Internum Mare ([[History of the Mediterranean region|Mediterranean Sea]]) **[[Hibernia]]-[[Scandinavia]] **Asia Occidentalis ([[Southwest Asia]]) **[[South Arabia|Arabia]]-[[Azania]] **[[India]] **Asia Orientalis ([[Bactria]], [[Sogdiana]], [[Arachosia]], [[Indus]] valley) *Then 93 maps are divided into six regional categories : **Part 1: Europa Septentrionalis ([[Northern Europe]]) **Part 2: [[Hispania]]-[[Ancient Libya|Libya]] **Part 3: [[Italia (Roman province)|Italia]] **Part 4: [[Greece|Graecia]]-[[Asia Minor]] **Part 5: [[Greater Syria|Syria]]-[[Meroe]] **Part 6: [[Pontus Euxinus]]-[[Persian Gulf|Persicus Sinus]]-Bactria *Then the provinces of the Roman Empire are presented in three 1:10,000,000 maps: **Provinces at the death of [[Trajan]] (117) **Dioceses and provinces according to the [[Verona List]] (c. 303-324) **Dioceses and provinces according to [[Synecdemus]] of [[Hierocles (author of Synecdemus)|Hierocles]] (late 5th - early 6th century) *Gazetteer
==Map-by-map directory contents== The two volumes<ref name="Talbert2000">{{cite book|editor=Richard J. A. Talbert|title=Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World: Map-by-Map Directory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x_FHmc_E2uQC|year=2000|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=0-691-04945-9}}</ref> (and the CD-ROM) contain: * Guidelines * Abbreviations * A separate directory for each map whose main components are: ** an introductory text ** a listing of names and features (with period, modern name and literature reference information) ** a bibliography
The CD-ROM also contains the gazetteer in PDF format and an installer of the version 4 of [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]] [[Acrobat Reader]] with Search for [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[Mac OS X]]. However, on Windows systems with the latest version of the Adobe Acrobat Reader already installed, installation of the version 4 might lead to incompatibility problems.
The supplied PDF index file BATLINDX.PDX is readable for Acrobat Reader versions up to and including version 9. For version X and later, using the "Use Advanced Search Options" item in the "Edit" menu may be a workaround. However, searching the complete index directory will take a while and with each new search the scanning of PDF files starts again from scratch. In general it will be faster to look for a name in the index. So, though the atlas claims to be "a reference work of permanent value",<ref>{{cite web|author=Tom Elliott |url=http://www.unc.edu/depts/cl_atlas/ |title=Classical Atlas Project |website=Unc.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref> a simple Acrobat Reader update will cripple its usability even for users who have the printed version of the map-by-map directory available, because the index shows only the main entries for each object.
The map-by-map directory and the gazetteer are also available in PDF format at the Princeton University Press website.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://press.princeton.edu/B_ATLAS/B_ATLAS.PDF |format=PDF |title=Map-By-Map Directory |website=Press.princeton.edu |accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref> Until 2013, a free download of the CD-ROM as a [[ZIP file]] was offered as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://press.princeton.edu/B_ATLAS.ZIP |format=ZIP |title=Atlas |website=Web.archive.org |accessdate=2017-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130507083500/http://press.princeton.edu/B_ATLAS.ZIP |archivedate=2013-05-07 |df= }}</ref>
==iPad version== In November 2013, PUP released an iPad 2+ App version of the Atlas which retailed at a 95% discount from the hardcover edition making it more accessible to the average reader.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://awmc.unc.edu/wordpress/blog/2013/10/31/barrington-atlas-of-the-greek-and-roman-world-for-ipad-2/|title=''Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World'' for iPad 2+|work=Ancient World Mapping Center|publisher=University of North Carolina|date=October 31, 2013|accessdate=December 21, 2013}}</ref><ref name=NYT-Biersdorfer>{{cite news|author=J. D. Biersdorfer|date=August 24, 2014|title=Gateways to the Classical World|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/24/books/review/gateways-to-the-classical-world.html|newspaper=The New York Times|page=BR8}}</ref> It contains the complete contents of the atlas and is searchable.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/apps/barrington-atlas/ |title=Talbert, R.J.A., ed.: Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World for iPad |website=Press.princeton.edu |date=2013-10-31 |accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref>
==Current editions== * Hardback (cloth) with CD-ROM Map-by-Map Directory, 2000, {{ISBN|0-691-03169-X}} * Hardback (cloth) with CD-ROM & two-volume 1,500 page Map-by-Map Directory, 2000, {{ISBN|0-691-04962-9}} * Hardback (cloth) two-volume Map-by-Map Directory, 2000, {{ISBN|0-691-04945-9}} * Digital (iPad 2+ App), 2013
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite news|author=[[Jasper Griffin]]|date=April 26, 2001|title=From Abakainon to Zygris|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/2001/04/26/from-abakainon-to-zygris/|newspaper=[[The New York Review of Books]]|pages=60–62}} * {{cite journal|author1=[[Susan E. Alcock]]|author2=Hendrik W. Dey|author3=[[Grant Parker]]|title=Sitting down with the ''Barrington Atlas''|url=http://www.journalofromanarch.com/samples/barrington.html|journal=Journal of Roman Archaeology|volume=14|pages=456–461|doi=10.1017/S1047759400020067|year=2001}} * {{cite journal|author=[[Paul Cartledge]]|title=''Barrington Atlas of the Greek and Roman World''|jstor=3298395|journal=[[The Classical Journal]]|volume=97|issue=2|pages=193–195|year=December 2001}} * {{cite journal|author=[[Kai Brodersen]]|title=Mapping (in) the Ancient World|jstor=4135015|journal=[[The Journal of Roman Studies]]|volume=94|pages=183–190|doi=10.2307/4135015|year=2004}}
==External links== * [http://press.princeton.edu/titles/6773.html Princeton University Press] * [http://www.unc.edu/depts/cl_atlas/ Classical Atlas Project] * [http://awmc.unc.edu/ Ancient World Mapping Center] * [http://pleiades.stoa.org Pleiades Project]
{{Italic title}}

[[File:Atafutrim.jpg|thumb|right|275px|[[Atoll]]s like [[Atafu]] in [[Tokelau]] in the Pacific Ocean are landforms associated to tropical climate. No atoll exists outside the tropics.]] '''Climatic geomorphology''' is the study of the role of climate in shaping landforms and the earth-surface processes.{{cite book|chapter-url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/285964375_Climatic_Geomorphology|chapter=Climatic Geomorphology|title=Treatise on Geomorphology|volume=13|author-last=Gutiérrez|first=Mateo |last2=Gutiérrez|first2=Francisco|year=2013|pages=115–131}} An approach used in climatic geomorphology is to study [[relict (geology)|relict landforms]] to infer ancient climates. Being often concerned about past climates climatic geomorphology considered sometimes to be an aspect of [[historical geology]].{{cite book |last= |first= |date=2005|chapter=Chapter 1 Climatic geomorphology |title=Developments in Earth Surface Processes|editor-last=Gutiérrez|editor-first=Mateo |url= |location= |publisher=|volume=8 |pages=3–32 |isbn= |author-link=|doi=10.1016/S0928-2025(05)80051-3|ISBN=978-0-444-51794-4}} Since landscape features in one region might have evolved under climates different than today, studying climatically disparate regions might help understand present-day landscapes. For example, [[Julius Büdel]] studied both [[periglacial|cold-climate]] processes in [[Svalbard]] and [[weathering]] processes in tropical [[India]] to understand the origin of the relief of [[Central Europe]], which he argued was a [[Palimpsest (geology)|palimpsest]] of landforms formed at different times and under different climates.{{cite journal |last1=Migoń |first1=Piotr |author-link=Piotr Migoń |first2= |date=2006 |title=Büdel, J. 1982: Climatic geomorphology. Princeton: Princeton University Press. (Translation of Klima-geomorphologie, Berlin-Stuttgart: Gebrüder Borntraeger, 1977.) |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1191/0309133306pp473xx |journal=[[Progress in Physical Geography]] |volume=30 |issue=1 |pages=99–103 |doi= |access-date= }} ==Sub-disciplines== The various subbranches of climatic geomorhpology focus on specific climatic environments. ===Desert geomorphology=== Desert geomorphology or the geomorphology of arid and semi-arid lands shares many landsforms and processes with more humid regions. One distinctive feature is the sparse or lacking [[vegetation]] cover, which influences fluvial and slope processes, related to [[aeolian processes|wind]] and [[Weathering#Salt_weathering|salt activity]].Goudie 2013, p. 1 Early work on desert geomorphology was done by Western explorers of the colonies of their respective countries in Africa ([[French West Africa]], [[German South West Africa]], [[Libyan Desert|Western Egypt]]), in frontier regions of their own countries ([[Western United States|American West]], [[Outback|Australian Outback]]) or in the deserts of foreign countries such as the [[Ottoman Empire]], the [[Russian Empire]] and [[China]].Goudie 2013, pp. 2–4 Since the 1970s desert geomorphology in Earth has served to find analogues to [[Geology of Mars|Martian landscapes]].Goudie 2013, p. 7 ===Periglacial geomorphology=== {{further|Periglaciation}} As a discipline periglacial geomorphology is close but different to [[Quaternary science]] and [[geocryology]]. Periglacial geomorphology is concerned with non-glacial cold-climate landforms in areas with and without [[permafrost]].French 2007, p. 8 Albeit the definition of what a periglacial zone is not clear-cut a conservative estimate is that a quarter of Earth's land surface has periglacial conditions. Beyond this quarter an additional quarter or fifth or Earth's land surface had periglacial conditions at some time during the [[Pleistocene]].French 2007, pp. 11–13 In periglacial geomorphology noted researchers include [[Johan Gunnar Andersson]], [[Walery Łoziński]], [[Anders Rapp]] and [[Jean Tricart]]. ===Tropical geomorphology=== If the tropics is defined as the area between 35° N and 35° S, then about 60% of Earth's surface lies within this zone.Gupta 2011, pp. 3–4 During most of the 20th century tropical geomorphology was neglected due to a bias towards [[temperate climate]]s, and when dealt with it was highlighted as "[[Exoticism|exotic]]". Tropical geomorphology do mainly differ from other areas in the intensities and rates at which surface processes operate, and not by the type of processes.Gupta 2011, "Foreword" The tropics are characterized by particular climates, that may be dry or humid. Relative to [[temperate zone]]s the tropics contain areas of high temperatures, high [[rainfall intensity|rainfall intensities]] and high [[evapotranspiration]] all of which are climatic features relevant for surface processes. Another characteristic, that is not related to present-day climate per see, is that a large portion of the tropics have a [[planation surface|low relief]] which was inherited from the continent of [[Gondwana]].Gupta 2011, pp. xiii{{efn-ua|See for example the extensive [[African Surface]].}} Julius Büdel, Pierre Birot and Jean Tricart have suggested that tropical rivers are dominated by fine-grained suspended load derived from advanced [[chemical weathering]], and this would make them less erosive than rivers elsewhere. Some landforms previously thought as typically tropical like [[bornhardt]]s are more related to [[lithology]] and [[structural geology|rock structure]] than climate.{{cite encyclopedia|last=Thomas|first=Michael F.|editor-last=Goudie|editor-first=A.S.|editor-link=Andrew Goudie (geographer)|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Geomorphology|title=Tropical geomorphology|year=2004|pages=1063–1069}} ==Morphoclimatic zones== [[File:Lut Desert Yardangs by Hadi Karimi.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Yardang]]s in [[Lut Desert]], [[Kerman Province]], [[Iran]]. Deserts constitute undisputed morphoclimatic zones.]] Climatic geomorphologists have devised various schemes that divide Earth's surface into various [[morphoclimatic zones]]; that is, zones where landforms are associated to present or past climates. However, only some processes and landforms can be associated with particular climates, meaning that they are ''zonal;'' processes and landforms not associated with particular climates are labelled ''[[azonal]]''. Despite this, azonal processes and landforms might still take on particular characteristics when developing under the influence of particular climates.French 2007, pp. 248–268 When identified, morphoclimatic zones do usually lack sharp boundaries and tend to grade from one type to another resulting in that only the core of the zone has all expected attributes. Influential morphoclimatic zoning schemes are those of [[Julius Büdel]] (1948, 1963, 1977) and of [[Jean Tricart]] and [[André Cailleux]] (1965). Büdel's schemes stresses [[planation surface|planation]] and [[river incision|valley-cutting]] in relation to climate, arguing the valley-cutting is dominant in subpolar regions while planation is so in the tropics. As such this scheme is concerned not only with processes but also with end-products of geomorphic activity. The scheme of Tricart and Cailleux emphasizes the relationship between geomorphology, climate and vegetation.{{cite book |last=Sarre |first=R.D. |date=1993 |chapter=Climatic geomorphology |url=https://books.google.fi/books?id=6uchDIKQV0UC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=%22Peritropical+zone+of+excessive+planation%22&source=bl&ots=n4rwR-esfY&sig=eJyN50pe41wIm6SUP8Wqy0Sck0Q&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Peritropical%20zone%20of%20excessive%20planation%22&f=false|title=The Encyclopedia of the Solid Earth Sciences|editor-last=Kearey|editor-first=Philip |location= |publisher=Blackwell Science Ltd. |page=112–114 |isbn=0-632-03699-0 }} An early attempt at morphoclimatic zoning is that of [[Albrecht Penck]] in 1910, who divided Earth in three zones depending on the [[evaporation]]-[[precipitation]] ratios. A 1994 review argues that only the concepts of [[desert]], [[glaciation|glacial]], [[periglaciation|periglacial]] and a few coastal{{efn-ua|[[Coral reef]]s occur only in tropical waters.}} morphoclimatic zones are justified. These zones amounts to about half of Earth's land surface, the remaining half cannot be explained in simple terms by climate-landform interactions.{{cite journal |last1=Twidale |first1=C.R. |author-link=Charles Rowland Twidale|last2=Lageat |first2=Y. |date=1994 |title=Climatic geomorphology: a critique |url= |journal=[[Progress in Physical Geography]] |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=319–334 |doi= |access-date= }} The limitations of morphoclimatic zoning were already discussed by [[Siegfried Passarge]] in 1926 who considered vegetation and the extent of [[regolith|weathered material]] as having more direct impact than climate in many parts of the World. According to M.A. Summerfield large-scale zoning of the [[Terrain|relief]] of Earth's surface is better explained on the basis of [[plate tectonics]] than on climate.Summerfield, M.A. (ed.). (2000), Geomorphology and global tectonics, Wiley. An example of this are the [[Scandinavian Mountains#Geology|Scandinavian Mountains]] whose [[paleic surface|plateau areas]] and valleys relate to the history of uplift and not to climate. [[Piotr Migoń]] has questioned the validity of certain morphoclimatic zonation schemes since they are named after processes, like [[planation surface|planation]], that might not occurring at all in large swathes of the zone. Referring to the 1977 scheme of Büdel Migoń states:
Is it really helpful to have the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt|Volcanic Cordillera of Mexico]], coastal ranges of southeast Brazil, plains of [[East Africa]], the escarpments of [[Western Ghats]] and the mountains of [[Taiwan]] in the same zone, labelled as the ‘peritropical zone of excessive planation’?
{| class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" |+ class="nowrap" | Morphogenetic zones according to Büdel (1977) ! Zone!! scope="col" style="width: 100px;" |Latitude !!Example |- | Glacial zone (and immediately adjacent area) || 90–65° N
60–90° S|| [[Greenland]], [[Antarctica]] |- | Subpolar zone of excessive valley cutting || 80–60° N || [[Canadian Arctic]], [[Taymyr Peninsula]] |- | [[Taiga]] valley cutting zone, in the [[permafrost]] region || 70–50° N ||[[Russian Far East]] |- | Ectropic zone of retarded valley cutting || 60–35° N
35–55° S ||Most of Europe, [[Patagonia]], [[Eurasian Steppe]] |- | Subtropic zone of mixed relief development, [[etesian]] region|| 40–30° N
30–35° S|| [[Morocco]], [[Syria]], [[Central Chile]]. |- | Subtropic zone of mixed relief development, [[monsoon]]al region || 45–25° N
20–40° S || [[Uruguay]], [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Korea]] |- | Peritropical zone of excessive planation|| 30° N–30° S || [[Venezuela]], [[Angola]], [[Mozambique]], [[Vietnam]] |- | Inter-tropical zone of partial planation || 20° N–10° S ||[[Panama]], [[Gabon]], [[Sumatra]] |- | Warm arid zone of [[Paleosurface|surface preservation]] and traditionally continued development, largely through fluvio-[[eolian processes|aeolian]] [[sandplain]]s || 35–10° N
5–30° S||[[Atacama Desert|Atacama]], [[Sahara]], [[Thar Desert|Thar]], [[Outback|Australian Outback]] |- | Winter cold arid zone of surface transformation, largely through [[pediment (geology)|pediment]]s and [[glacis (geology)|glacis]]|| 50–30° N || [[Gobi Desert|Gobi]], [[Taklamakan Desert|Taklamakan]], [[Maranjab Desert|Maranjab]] |} ==Historical development== During the age of [[New Imperialism]] in the late 19th century European explorers and scientists traveled across the globe bringing descriptions of landscapes and landforms. As geographical knowledge increased over time these observations were systematized in a search for regional patterns. Climate emerged thus as prime factor for explaining landform distribution at a grand scale. The rise of climatic geomorphology was foreshadowed by the work of [[Wladimir Köppen]], [[Vasily Dokuchaev]] and [[Andreas Franz Wilhelm Schimper|Andreas Schimper]]. [[William Morris Davis]], the leading geomorphologist of his time, recognized the role of climate by complementing his "normal" temperate climate [[cycle of erosion]] with arid and glacial ones.{{cite encyclopedia|last=Goudie|first=A.S.|editor-last=Goudie|editor-first=A.S.|author-link=Andrew Goudie (geographer)|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Geomorphology|title=Climatic geomorphology|year=2004|pages=162–164}} Nevertheless, interest in climatic geomorphology was also a reaction ''against'' [[Cycle of erosion|Davisian geomorphology]] that was by the mid-20th century considered both un-innovative and dubious.{{cite journal |last=Flemal |first=Ronald C. |last2= |first2= |date=1971 |title=The Attack on the Davisian System Of Geomorphology: A Synopsis |url= |journal= |volume= |issue= |pages=3–13 |doi= |access-date= }} Early climatic geomorphology developed primarily in [[continental Europe]] while in the English-speaking world the tendency was not explicit until L.C. Peltier's 1950 publication on a [[periglaciation|periglacial]] cycle of erosion. Climatic geomorphology was criticized in a 1969 [[review article]] by [[Geomorphology#Quantitative_and_process_geomorphology|process geomorphologist]] [[David Stoddart (geographer)|D.R. Stoddart]]. The criticism by Stoddart proved "devastating" sparking a decline in the popularity of climatic geomorphology in the late 20th century. Stoddart criticized climatic geomorphology for applying supposedly "trivial" methodologies in establishing landform differences between morphoclimatic zones, being linked to [[Cycle of erosion|Davisian geomorphology]] and by allegedly neglecting the fact that physical laws governing processes are the same across the globe. In addition some conceptions of climatic geomorphology, like that which holds that chemical weathering is more rapid in tropical climates than in cold climates proved to not be straightforwardly true. Despite having diminished in importance, climatic geomorphology continues to exist as a field of study producing relevant research. More recently, concerns over [[global warming]] have led to a renewed interest in the field. == Notes == {{notelist-ua}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ;Bibliography *{{cite book|first=Hugh M.|last=French|title=The Periglacial Environment|edition=3rd|date=2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons Ltd.|isbn=978-0-470-86588-0|pages=458}} *{{cite book|first=Andrew S.|last=Goudie|title=Arid and Semi-Arid Geomorphology|edition=|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-107-00554-9|pages=454}} *{{cite book |last=Gupta |first=Avijit |date=2011 |title=Tropical Geomorphology |url= |location= |publisher=Cambridge University Press |pages=394 |author-link=|chapter=Introduction |ISBN=978-0-521-87990-3}} [[Category:Climatology]] [[Category:Geomorphology]] [[Category:Paleoclimatology]]

{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[File:Un-kenya.png|thumb|400px|A United Nations map of Kenya]] [[File:LocationKenya.svg|thumb|Location of Kenya]] The '''[[geography]] of [[Kenya]]''' is diverse, varying amongst Kenya's [[Counties of Kenya|47 Counties]]. [[Kenya]] has a coastline on the Indian Ocean, which contains swamps of [[East African mangroves]]. Inland are broad plains and numerous hills. Central and Western Kenya is characterised by the [[Kenyan Rift Valley]] and central province home to the highest mountain, [[Mount Kenya]] and [[Mount Elgon]] on the border between Kenya and Uganda. The [[Kakamega Forest]] in western Kenya is a relic of an East African rainforest. Much bigger is [[Mau Forest]], the largest forest complex in East Africa. == Geography == === Location === * Eastern Africa on the [[Indian Ocean]] coast between [[Somalia]] and [[Tanzania]] * [[Geographic coordinates]]: {{coord|1|00|N|38|00|E|type:country}} Central Karachi, two kilometres from the Laalu Khet 4 Number === Area === * Total: {{convert|582650|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} * Land: {{convert|569140|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} * Water: {{convert|11227|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} === Land boundaries === * Total: {{convert|3457|km|mi|abbr=on}} * Border countries: [[Ethiopia]] {{convert|867|km|mi|abbr=on}}, [[Somalia]] {{convert|684|km|mi|abbr=on}}, [[South Sudan]] {{convert|317|km|mi|abbr=on}}, [[Tanzania]] {{convert|775|km|mi|abbr=on}}, [[Uganda]] {{convert|814|km|mi|abbr=on}}[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ke.html cia.gov – The World Factbook Kenya] ==Coastline== [[File:Kenya sat.png|thumb|350px|A satellite image of Kenya.]] * 536 km (333 mi) along the Indian Ocean. ===Maritime claims=== * Territorial sea: {{convert|12|nmi|km mi|1|abbr=on}} * Exclusive economic zone: {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|1|abbr=on|lk=in}} * Continental shelf: 200 m depth or to the depth of exploitation ==Geology== Much of the western two-thirds of the country consists of the [[Pliocene]]–[[Pleistocene]] volcanics deposited on [[Precambrian]] basement rocks.[http://www.epgeology.com/articles/kenya-rift-basin.html Petroleum Potential of NW-Kenya Rift Basins: A Synopsis of Evidence and Issues] The southeast corner of the country is underlain by sediments of the [[Karoo System]] of [[Permian]] to [[Late Triassic]] age and a strip of [[Jurassic]] age sediments along the coast in the [[Mombasa]] area. The [[Anza trough]] is a NW–SE trending Jurassic rift extending from the Indian Ocean coast to the Sudan northwest of Lake Turkana. The Anza Rift resulted from the break–up of [[Gondwana]].{{cite journal|url=http://www.mendeley.com/research/crustal-structure-tectonic-evolution-anza-rift-northern-kenya/ |title=Crustal structure and tectonic evolution of the Anza rift, northern Kenya |author1=L C Greene |author2=D R Richards |author3=R A Johnson |journal=Tectonophysics |year=1991 | volume= 197 | issue= 2–4 | pages= 203–211 |accessdate=2011-11-20 | doi=10.1016/0040-1951(91)90041-P}} ==Climate== [[File:Kenya map of Köppen climate classification.svg|thumb|300px|Kenya map of Köppen climate classification]] The climate of Kenya varies by location, from mostly cool every day, to always warm/hot. The climate along the coast is tropical. This means rainfall and temperatures are higher throughout the year. At the coastal cities, Mombasa, Lamu and Malindi, the air changes from cool to hot, almost every day. (''See chart below''). The further inside Kenya, the more arid the climate becomes. An arid climate is nearly devoid of rainfall, and temperature swings widely according to the general time of the day/night. For many areas of Kenya, the daytime temperature rises about 12 °C (corresponding to a rise of about 22 °F), almost every day. Elevation is the major factor in temperature levels, with the higher areas, on average, as 11 °C (20 °F) cooler, day or night. "NairobiDagoretti, Kenya: Climate, Global Warming, and Daylight Charts and Data", Climate-Charts.com, 2008, web: [http://www.climate-charts.com/Locations/k/KN63741.php CC741]: compare [[Nairobi]]/[[Dagoretti]] data with or [[Mombasa]] charts. "Kitale, Kenya: Climate, Global Warming, and Daylight Charts and Data", Climate-Charts.com, 2008, web: [http://www.climate-charts.com/Locations/k/KN63661.php CC661]. The many cities over a kilometre in elevation have temperature swings from roughly {{convert|50|-|79|F|C|order=flip}}. Nairobi, at {{convert|1798|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, ranges from {{convert|49|-|80|F|C|order=flip}}, and [[Kitale]], at {{convert|1825|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, ranges from {{convert|51|-|82|F|C|order=flip}}. At night, heavy clothes or blankets are needed, in the highlands, when the temperature drops to about {{convert|50|-|54|F|C|order=flip}} every night. At lower altitudes, the increased temperature is like day and night, literally: like starting the morning at the highland daytime high, and then adding the heat of the day, again. Hence, the overnight low temperatures near sea level are nearly the same as the high temperatures of the elevated Kenyan highlands. However, locations along the Indian Ocean have more moderate temperatures, as a few degrees cooler in the daytime, such as at [[Mombasa]] (''see chart below''). There are slight seasonal variations in temperature, of {{convert|4|C-change|disp=or}}, cooler in the winter months. Although Kenya is centred at the [[equator]], it shares the seasons of the [[southern hemisphere]]: with the warmest summer months in December–March and the coolest winter months in June–August, again with differences in temperature varying by location within the country. On the high mountains, such as [[Mount Kenya]], [[Mount Elgon]] and [[Kilimanjaro]], the weather can become bitterly cold for most of the year. Some snowfall occurs on the highest mountains. {| class=wikitable width=590px |- !colspan=16|Climate data for Mombasa (at Indian Ocean) "Mombasa, Kenya: Climate, Global Warming, and Daylight Charts and Data", Climate-Charts.com, 2008, web: [http://www.climate-charts.com/Locations/k/KN63820.php CC820]: May precipitation was reset as "246" mm, converting 9.7 in. |- bgcolor=#EEEEEE |width="1%"|NOAA Code||Statistic||Jan||Feb||Mar||Apr||May||Jun||Jul||Aug||Sep||Oct||Nov||Dec||Avg |- |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0101||Temperature
Average F||81.7||82.6||82.9||81.7||79.2||76.6||75.2||75.2||76.5||78.3||80.4||81.3||79.3 |- bgcolor=#FFCC22 |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0201||bgcolor=#FFFFFF|Temperature
High value F||91.8||92.7||92.7||90.5||87.6||bgcolor=#EEEE77|84.9||bgcolor=#EEEE77|83.7||bgcolor=#EEEE77|83.8||bgcolor=#EEEE77|85.5||86.9||88.9||91||88.3 |- bgcolor=#EEDDFF |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0301||bgcolor=#FFFFFF|Temperature
Low value F||71.6||72.5||73.2||72.9||70.9||bgcolor=#EECCFF|68.2||bgcolor=#EEBBFF|66.7||bgcolor=#EEBBFF|66.7||bgcolor=#EECCFF|67.5||bgcolor=#EECCFF|69.6||71.8||71.6||70.3 |- bgcolor=#99CCFF |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0615||Precipitation
in inches||1.4||0.6||2.3||bgcolor=#AABBFF|6.3 ||bgcolor=#99AAFF|9.7||3.6||2.9||2.8||2.8||bgcolor=#99BBFF|4.2||bgcolor=#99BBFF|4.3||3.1||3.7 |- |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0101||Temperature
Average C||27.6||28.1||28.3||27.6 ||26.2||24.8||24.0||24.0||24.7||25.7||26.9||27.4||26.27 |- bgcolor=#FFCC22 |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0201||bgcolor=#FFFFFF|Temperature
High value C||33.2||33.7||33.7||32.5 ||30.9||bgcolor=#EEEE77|29.4||bgcolor=#EEEE77|28.7||bgcolor=#EEEE77|28.8||bgcolor=#EEEE77|29.7||30.5||31.6||32.8||31.29 |- bgcolor=#EEDDFF |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0301||bgcolor=#FFFFFF|Temperature
Low value C||22.0||22.5||22.9||22.7 ||21.6||bgcolor=#EECCFF|20.1||bgcolor=#EEBBFF|19.3||bgcolor=#EEBBFF|19.3||bgcolor=#EECCFF|19.7||bgcolor=#EECCFF|20.9||22.1||22.0||21.26 |- bgcolor=#99CCFF |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|0615||Precipitation
in mm||33.9||14.0||55.6||bgcolor=#AABBFF|154.3 ||bgcolor=#99AAFF|246||88.3||71.8||68.2||67.2||bgcolor=#99BBFF|103.4||bgcolor=#99BBFF|104.7||75.8||89.39 |- |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|1109||Humidity
Maximum %||76.0||76.0||78.0||82.0 ||85.0||84.0||86.0||85.0||82.0||81.0||80.0||78.0||81.08 |- |bgcolor=#E7E7E7|1110||Humidity
Minimum %||62.0||59.0||61.0||66.0 ||70.0||67.0||67.0||66.0||65.0||66.0||68.0||65.0||65.17 |} ==Terrain== [[Image:Kenya Topography.png|thumb|350px|The topography of Kenya.]] Kenya's terrain is composed of low plains that rise into central highlands that are, in turn, bisected by the [[Great Rift Valley]]. There is also a fertile plateau in the west of the country. ===Elevation extremes=== The lowest point on Kenya is at sea level on the Indian Ocean. The highest point on Kenya is 5,197 meters above sea level at [[Mount Kenya]]. ===Rivers=== The three main rivers are the [[Athi-Galana-Sabaki River|Galana]] and the [[Tana River (Kenya)|Tana]] and The [[Nzoia River|Nzoia]] River which is a {{convert|257|km|mi|adj=mid|-long}} Kenyan river, rising from [[Mount Elgon]]. It flows south and then west, eventually flowing into [[Lake Victoria]] near the town of Port Victoria. However, the [[Ewaso Ng'iro]] is an important river, supplying water from [[Mt. Kenya]] to the eastern and north-eastern part of [[Kenya]]. ===Natural resources=== Natural resources that are found in Kenya include: limestone, soda ash, salt, gemstones, fluorspar, zinc, diatomite, oil, gas, gypsum, wildlife and hydropower. ===Land use=== 9.8% of the land is arable; permanent crops occupy 0.9% of the land, permanent pasture occupy 37.4% of the land; forest occupies 6.1% of the land. Other uses make up the rest of Kenya's land. This is as of 2011. 1032 km2 of Kenyan land was irrigated in 2003. ===Total renewable water resources=== 30.7 km3 (2011) ===Freshwater withdrawal=== * Total: 2.74 km3/yr (17%/4%/79%) * Per capita: 72.96 m3/yr (2003) ==Natural hazards== Natural hazards include recurring drought and flooding during the rainy seasons. There is limited volcanic activity in the country. [[Barrier Volcano]] (elev. 1,032 m) last erupted in 1921. Several others have been historically active (see [[List of volcanoes in Kenya]]). ===Environmental issues=== {{main|Environmental issues in Kenya}} ====Current issues==== Current issues that threaten the environment at the moment include water pollution from urban and industrial wastes; degradation of water quality from the increased use of pesticides and fertilisers; [[deforestation]]; [[water hyacinth]] infestation in [[Lake Victoria]]; [[soil erosion]]; [[desertification]]; and poaching. ====International agreements==== * Party to: [[Biodiversity]], [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|Climate Change]], [[Kyoto Protocol|Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol]], [[Desertification]], [[Endangered Species]], [[Hazardous Wastes]], [[Law of the Sea]], [[Marine Dumping]], [[Marine Life Conservation]], [[Ozone Layer Protection]], Ship Pollution ([[MARPOL 73/78]]), [[Wetlands]], [[Whaling]]. == Extreme points == This is a list of the extreme points of [[Kenya]], the points that are further north, south, east or west than any other location. * Northernmost point – [[Kalukwakerith]] Mountain, [[Turkana County]] * Easternmost point – the [[tripoint]] with [[Ethiopia]] and [[Somalia]], [[Mandera County]] * Southernmost point – the point where the border with [[Tanzania]] enters the Indian Ocean, [[Kwale County]] * Westernmost point – unnamed land west of [[Port Victoria, Kenya|Port Victoria]], [[Busia County]] ** ''Note: Kalukwakerith Mountain is in the disputed [[Ilemi Triangle]] region. If this area is excluded then Kenya does not have a northernmost point, the northern border being a straight line.'' ==See also== {{portal|Geography of Kenya|Kenya}} * [[Environmental issues in Kenya]] * [[List of national parks of Kenya]] * [[Ilemi Triangle]] * [[Mandera triangle]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Kenya topics}} {{Geography of Africa}} {{Africa topic|Climate of}} [[Category:Geography of Kenya| ]]
