revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Class of underwater acoustic positioning systems used to track underwater vehicles and divers" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Class of underwater acoustic positioning systems used to track underwater vehicles and divers}} [[File:LBL Acoustic Positioning System Aquamap Diver.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Figure 1: Method of the operation of a long baseline (LBL) acoustic positioning system]]
A '''long baseline (LBL) acoustic positioning system'''<ref>Underwater Acoustic Positioning Systems, Chapter 4, P.H. Milne, 1983, {{ISBN|0-87201-012-0}}</ref> is one of three broad classes of [[Underwater Acoustic Positioning System|underwater acoustic positioning systems]] that are used to track underwater vehicles and divers. The other two classes are [[Ultra-short baseline|ultra short baseline systems]] (USBL) and [[Short baseline acoustic positioning system|short baseline systems]] (SBL). LBL systems are unique in that they use networks of sea-floor mounted baseline transponders as reference points for navigation. These are generally deployed around the perimeter of a work site. The LBL technique results in very high positioning accuracy and position stability that is independent of water depth. It is generally better than 1-meter and can reach a few centimeters accuracy.<ref>NOAA Diving Manual, Edition 4, Underwater Navigation, Section 10.2., {{ISBN|0-941332-70-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-941332-70-5}}</ref> LBL systems are generally employed for precision underwater survey work where the accuracy or position stability of ship-based (SBL, USBL) positioning systems does not suffice.
== Operation and performance == [[File:AquaMap Diver LBL Acoustic Positioning Equipment.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Figure 2: A dive team (Envirotech Diving) with their AquaMap LBL acoustic underwater positioning system including three baseline transponders (B) and diver stations (A) mounted on scooters. The baseline stations are first deployed in the corners of a work site. Their relative position is then precisely measured using the AquaMap system's automatic acoustic self-survey capability. For geo-referenced operations, the baseline positions are surveyed by differential GPS or a laser positioning equipment (total station). During a dive, the diver station interrogates the baseline stations to measure the distances, which are then converted to positions.]]
Long baseline systems determine the position of a vehicle or diver by acoustically measuring the distance from a vehicle or diver interrogator to three or more seafloor deployed baseline transponders. These range measurements, which are often supplemented by depth data from pressure sensors on the devices, are then used to triangulate the position of the vehicle or diver. In figure 1, a diver mounted interrogator (A) sends a signal, which is received by the baseline transponders (B, C, D). The transponders reply, and the replies are received again by the diver station (A). Signal run time measurements now yield the distances A-B, A-C and A-D, which are used to compute the diver position by triangulation or position search algorithms. The resulting positions are relative to the location of the baseline transducers. These can be readily converted to a geo-referenced coordinate system such as latitude/longitude or UTM if the geo-positions of the baseline stations are first established.
Long baseline systems get their name from the fact that the spacing of the baseline transponders is long or similar to the distance between the diver or vehicle and the transponders.<ref>Handbook of Acoustics, Malcolm J. Crocker 1998, {{ISBN|0-471-25293-X}}, 9780471252931, page 462</ref> That is, the baseline transponders are typically mounted in the corners of an underwater work site within which the vehicle or diver operates. This method yields an ideal geometry for positioning, in which any given error in acoustic range measurements produce only about an equivalent position error.<ref>The ROV Manual, Robert D. Christ and Robert L. Wernli Sr, Section 4.2.8. Capabilities and Limitations of Acoustic Positioning, {{ISBN|978-0-7506-8148-3}}</ref> This compares to SBL and USBL systems with shorter baselines where ranging disturbances of a given amount can result in much larger position errors. Further, the mounting of the baseline transponders on the sea floor eliminates the need for converting between reference frames, as is the case for USBL or SBL positioning systems mounted on moving vessels.<ref>The ROV Manual, Section 4.2.6.4 Long Baseline (LBL)</ref> Finally, sea floor mounting makes the positioning accuracy independent of water depth.<ref>LBL Underwater Positioning, Hydro International Magazine, Jan/Feb 2008, Volume 12, Number 1</ref> For these reasons LBL systems are generally applied to tasks where the required standard of positioning accuracy or reliability exceeds the capabilities of USBL and SBL systems.
== History == The search and inspection of the lost nuclear submarine [[USS Thresher (SSN-593)|USS Thresher]] by the U.S. Navy oceanographic vessel [[USNS Mizar (T-AGOR-11)|USNS Mizar]] in 1963 is frequently credited as the origin of modern underwater acoustic navigation systems.<ref>Milne, Chapter 2</ref> Mizar primarily used a short baseline (SBL) system to track the bathyscaphe [[Bathyscaphe Trieste|Trieste 1]]. However, its capability also included seafloor transponders, which in conjunction with early navigation satellites supported station-keeping with a precision of about 300 feet, considered remarkable at the time.<ref>The Universe Below, Page 77, William J. Broad & Dimitry Schidlovski 1998, {{ISBN|0-684-83852-4}}, {{ISBN|978-0-684-83852-6}}</ref>
== Examples == [[File:Ohio-class submarine launches Tomahawk Cruise missiles (artist concept).jpg|thumb|right|Figure 3: Precisely establishing the position of nuclear submarines prior to missile launches was an early application of long baseline acoustic positioning systems. Covert networks of sea floor transponders could survive and provide a precision navigation capability even after GPS satellites had been knocked out.]]
By the mid-1960s and possibly earlier, the Soviets were developing underwater navigation systems including seafloor transponders to allow nuclear submarines to operate precisely while staying submerged.<ref>History of Russian Underwater Acoustics, page 722. Oleg A. Godin, David R. Palmer, 2008, {{ISBN|981-256-825-5}}, {{ISBN|978-981-256-825-0}}</ref> Besides navigating through canyons and other difficult underwater terrain, there was also a need to establish the position of the submarine prior to the launch of a nuclear missile (ICBM). In 1981, acoustic positioning was proposed as part of the U.S. military's [[LGM-118 Peacekeeper|MX missile]] system.<ref>MX Missile Basing, pages 173-175, 1981, {{ISBN|1-4289-2450-7}}, {{ISBN|978-1-4289-2450-5}}</ref> A network of 150 covert transponder fields was envisioned. Submarines typically are guided by inertial navigation systems, but these dead reckoning systems develop position drift which must be corrected by occasional position fixes from a GNSS system. If the enemy were to knock out the GNSS satellites, the submarine could rely on the covert transponder network to establish its position and program the missile's own inertial navigation system for launch.
{{clear}}
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{hydroacoustics}}
[[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Surveying]] [[Category:Oceanography]]

revision.text:
[[File:Loxodrome.png|thumb|300px | Rhumb line navigation path: β = constant]] '''Loxodromic navigation''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] ''λοξóς'', oblique, and ''δρóμος'', path) is a method of navigation by following a [[rhumb line]], a curve on the surface of the [[Earth (planet)|Earth]] that follows the same angle at the intersection with each [[Meridian (geography)|meridian]]. This serves to maintain a steady course in sailing.<ref name="WeintritNeumann2011">{{cite book|author1=Adam Weintrit|author2=Tomasz Neumann|title=Methods and Algorithms in Navigation: Marine Navigation and Safety of Sea Transportation|url=https://books.google.es/books?id=buMsPGyE7boC&pg=PA139&lpg=PA139&dq=loxodromic+navigation&source=bl&ots=GIZeu8DBp5&sig=1UcvzLLnZjKTSpaS9ECPnMmpidU&hl=ca&sa=X&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBWoVChMIq9ztmPzSyAIViXEUCh03eAKe#v=onepage&q=loxodromic%20navigation&f=false|date=7 June 2011|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-415-69114-7|pages=139–}}</ref>
Navigating on a spherical surface with a fixed [[course (navigation)|course]] (<math>\beta </math> in the figure) results in a spiral path that approaches the [[North Pole]] for courses ranging from 270º to 090º and the [[South Pole]] for courses from 090º to 270º. On a [[nautical chart]] plotted according to the [[Mercator projection]], a loxodromic course appears as a straight line.
== Comparison Chart == [[File:Orthodromic vs loxodromic.png|center | thumb | 400 px | Comparison, of [[Great Circle|orthodromic]] course (white) compared with a [[Rhumb line|loxodromic]] course (red).]]
== See also == * [[Great circle navigation]]. * [[Windrose network]]. * [[Map]] * [[Portolan map]] * [[Marine sandglass]] * [[Compass rose]] * [[Isoazimuthal]]
==References== {{reflist}} *http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=6233256
== External links == * [http://sites.google.com/site/navigational algorithms/ assistance program for loxodromic navigation]
[[Category:Navigation]]

revision.text:
Whereas originally the term [[Navigation]] applies to the process of directing a ship to a destination, '''Navigation research''' deals with fundamental aspects of navigation in general. It can be defined as "The process of determining and maintaining a course or trajectory to a goal location" (Franz, Mallot, 2000). It concerns basically all moving [[Agent (grammar)|agents]], [[biology|biological]] or artificial, [[Wiktionary:autonomy|autonomous]] or remote-controlled.
Franz and Mallot proposed a navigation hierarchy in ''Robotics and Autonomous Systems 30'' (2006):<ref name=FM1>{{cite book|author=Franz|author2=Mallot|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6V16-3YHG97R-K&_user=946230&_coverDate=01%2F31%2F2000&_rdoc=9&_fmt=summary&_orig=browse&_srch=%23toc%235666%232000%23999699998%23159597!&_cdi=5666&_sort=d&_docanchor=&_acct=C000049009&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=946230&md5=8c30c4f00f8e97c08651032b4d118e90|title=Robotics and Autonomous Systems 30|year=2000|pages=133–153}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" ! || Behavioural prerequisite || Navigation competence |- ! colspan="3" | Local navigation |- |Search || Goal recognition || Finding the goal without active goal orientation |- |Direction-following || Align course with local direction || Finding the goal from one direction |- |Aiming || Keep goal in front || Finding a salient goal from a catchment area |- |Guidance || Attain spatial relation to the surrounding objects || Finding a goal defined by its relation to the surroundings |- ! colspan="3" | Way-finding |- |Recognition-triggered response || Association sensory pattern-action || Following fixed routes |- |Topological navigation || Route integration, route planning || Flexible concatenation of route segments |- |Survey navigation || Embedding into a common reference frame || Finding paths over novel terrain |}
There are two basic methods for navigation:
* [[Egocentric navigation]] also known as Idiothetic navigation * [[Allocentric navigation]] also known as Allothetic navigation
== Human navigation== In human navigation people visualize different routes in their minds to plan how to get from one place to another. The things which they rely on to plan these routes vary from person to person and are the basis of the differing navigational strategies.
Some people use measures of distance and absolute directional terms (north, south, east, and west) in order to visualize the best pathway from point to point. The use of these more general, external cues as directions is considered part of an allocentric navigation strategy. [[Allocentric navigation]] is typically seen in males and is beneficial primarily in large and/or unfamiliar environments.<ref name= "one">Andreano & Cahill (2009)</ref> This likely has some basis in evolution when males would have to navigate through large and unfamiliar environments while hunting.<ref name= "two">Geary (1998)</ref> The use of allocentric strategies when navigating primarily activates the hippocampus and parahippocampus in the brain. This navigation strategy relies more on a mental, spatial map than visible cues, giving it an advantage in unknown areas but a flexibility to be used in smaller environments as well. The fact that it is mainly males that favor this strategy is likely related to the generalization that males are better navigators than females as it is better able to be applied in a greater variety of settings.<ref name="one" />
[[Egocentric navigation]] relies on more local landmarks and personal directions (left/right) to navigate and visualize a pathway. This reliance on more local and well-known stimuli for finding their way makes it difficult to apply in new locations, but is instead most effective in smaller, familiar environments.<ref name="one" /> Evolutionarily, egocentric navigation likely comes from our ancestors who would forage for their food and need to be able to return to the same places daily to find edible plants. This foraging usually occurred in relatively nearby areas and was most commonly done by the females in hunter-gatherer societies.<ref name="two" /> Females, today, are typically better at knowing where various landmarks are and often rely on them when giving directions. Egocentric navigation causes high levels of activation in the right parietal lobe and prefrontal regions of the brain that are involved in visuospatial processing.<ref name="one" />
== Robotic navigation == {{Main|Robotic navigation}} [[Outdoor]] robots can use GPS in a similar way to [[automotive navigation system]]s. Alternative systems can be used with [[floor plan]] instead of [[map]]s for [[indoor]] robots, combined with localization wireless hardware.
== See also == * [[Electric beacon]] * [[Visual navigation]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Andreano, J. M., & Cahill, L. (2009). Sex influences on the neurobiology of learning and memory. Learning & memory, 16(4), 248-246. * Geary, D. C. (1998). Male, female: The evolution of human sex differences. (pp. 259-303). Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association.
[[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Robot navigation]]

{{Infobox historic site | name = Osu District | nrhp_type = | image = Osu marker.jpg | caption = | coordinates = {{coord|5|33|14|N|0|10|30|W|region:GH-AA_type:city_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=inline,title}} | location= Roughly:
W: Independence Avenue
SW: Castle Road/Sir Charles Quist Street
N/NE: Ring Road East
S: Gulf of Guinea | governing_body = Accra Metropolitan Assembly }} [[File:OsuGhana.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Aerial view]] Located about {{convert|3|km}} east of the central business district, '''Osu''' is a neighborhood in central [[Accra]], [[Ghana]], known for its busy commercial, restaurant and nightlife activity. It is locally known as the "West End" of Accra.[http://www.travel-to-discover-ghana.com/osu-oxford-street.html Osu Oxford Street] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205173118/http://www.travel-to-discover-ghana.com/osu-oxford-street.html |date=2015-02-05 }}. traveltodiscoverghana.com. Bounded to the south by the Gulf of Guinea, Osu's western boundary is the Independence Avenue. Ring Road separates Osu from the northern district of [[Labone, Accra|Labone]]. Owing to its establishment as a settlement around the Danish fort of [[Osu Castle|Christiansborg]] in the 17th century, Osu offers a mix of houses dating from the early 20th century (both low-rise apartment blocks and detached houses) to modern office towers. Ringway Estates, a [[gated community|gated residential community]] between Gamel Abdul Nasser Avenue and Cantonments Road is located in the western section of Osu. The main thoroughfare, Cantonments Road (colloquially known as Oxford Street) features large supermarkets and appliance shops, and is renowned for its food joints and lively nightlife. At its southern end is the site of the 17th-century [[Osu Castle|Fort Christiansborg]], a former [[Danish Gold Coast|Danish colonial]] fort, which formerly housed the seat of government, and relocated to [[The Flagstaff House]] near the 37 Military Hospital after it was reconstructed by Former President, [[John Kufuor]].[http://accra.wantedinafrica.com/area_description.php?id_area=354 Accra Medium Area: Labone/Osu (Christianborg)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811025541/http://accra.wantedinafrica.com/area_description.php?id_area=354 |date=2011-08-11 }}. accra.wantedinafrica.com. ==Osu-RE== Osu-RE located on "Oxford Street" is arguably the liveliest part of Accra and Ghana as a whole, the most preferred hang-out spot for tourists visiting the city. With most of the country's entertaining places located in the Osu-Re, the town hosts people with diverse cultures and entertainment from different countries. ==Economy== The head office of [[Starbow]] is in Osu."[http://www.flystarbow.com/?p=58 Contact us] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120827011013/http://www.flystarbow.com/?p=58 |date=2012-08-27 }}." [[Starbow]]. Retrieved on 6 May 2013. "832 First Street Adjacent to the Salvation Army Territorial Headquarters Osu, Accra" ==Landmarks/Places of interest== ===Dining=== {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| *Monsoon *Frankie's Restaurant *Bella Roma *Container *Osu Blue Gate *Osu Night market *Regal Chinese Restaurant *Papaye Fast Food *KFC *Chics & Ribs *18th Lane Resto *Xigi's *Rockafellas *Jeggous Place *Bloombar *Purple Pub *NourishLAB Smoothy's *Eyes Right *Night life *Hide Out *burger and relish }} ===Entertainment=== {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| *Honeysuckle Pub *Firefly Lounge *Baze Lounge and Bar *Don's Place *Shisha Lounge *Makumba night club *Piccadilly Casino *Venus Cocktail Bar *Duplex *Calabash night club *Republic Bar and Grill *Epo Sport *Hot Gossip *Sai Wine and Champagne Cafe *Purple Pub *Eyes Right *Bloombar }} ===Shopping=== *Oxford Street Mall *Koala Shopping Center *Lara Mart ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Ghana}} * {{Commons category-inline}} [[Category:Geography of Ghana]] [[Category:Accra]]

revision.text:
[[File:Crew of the Quest.jpg|upright|right|thumb|The crew of the ''Quest'' at the start of the expedition]] The [[Shackleton–Rowett Expedition]], 1921–22, was the last Antarctic expedition led by Sir [[Ernest Shackleton]]. Proposed as an ambitious two-year programme of Antarctic exploration it was curtailed by the death of Shackleton and the inadequacies of the expedition's ship, ''[[Quest (ship)|Quest]]''. Under the command of [[Frank Wild]] several attempts were made to break through the Antarctic pack ice, but the expedition was never able to proceed further than [[longitude]] 20°E. On the crew's return to [[Cape Town]] to refit in preparation for the second term they were ordered home. The crew of the ''Quest'' comprised 24 members in all, but only 19 were on board for the start of the Antarctic portion (Hussey accompanied Shackleton's body when it was put on board a ship for England, and Eriksen, Mooney and Bee-Mason had left before the ship reached [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]]). Gerald Lysaght, a yachtsman, accompanied the crew from [[Plymouth]] to [[Cape Verde]]. {|width=100% class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center;" !class="unsortable"|Name !!Born !!Died !!class="unsortable"|Position !!class="unsortable"|Additional information |- |[[Image:Shack-endurance.jpg|100x100px]]
[[Ernest Shackleton|Sir Ernest Shackleton]]||1874||1922||Commander|| Died on South Georgia during the expedition |- |[[Image:FrankWild.png|100x100px]]
[[Frank Wild]]||1873||1939||2nd in Command||Took command of the expedition on Shackleton's death. Had served as 2nd in Command on Shackleton's [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] |- |[[Image:Frank Worsley.jpg|100x100px]]
[[Frank Worsley]]||1872||1943||[[Captain (nautical)|Captain]] of ''Quest''||Formerly Captain of ''Endurance'' during the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[Alexander Kerr]]||1892||1964||Engineer||Served as 2nd Engineer on the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[James McIlroy (surgeon)|James McIlroy]]||1879||1968||[[Surgeon]]/[[Meteorologist]]||Veteran of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[Image:Macklin.jpeg|100x100px]]
[[Alexander Macklin]]||1889||1967||Surgeon/In charge of stores and equipment||Veteran of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[Image:Leonard Hussey.jpg|100x100px]]
[[Leonard Hussey]]||1891||1964||Meteorologist/Assistant Surgeon||Accompanied Shackleton's body to [[Montevideo]] and then back to South Georgia, so was not present for most of the expedition. Veteran of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[Image:CharlesGreen.png|100x100px]]
[[Charles Green (cook)|Charles Green]]||1888||1974||[[Chef|Cook]]||Veteran of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[Thomas McLeod (sailor)|Thomas McLeod]]||1869||1960||Able seaman||Veteran of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition |- |[[Roderick Carr]]||1891||1971||Pilot||Assisted with scientific work as the expedition's plane was unserviceable |- |[[James Dell]]||''c''.1880||1968||Electrician, Boatswain||Had been with Shackleton on the [[Discovery Expedition]] |- |[[George Hubert Wilkins|Hubert Wilkins]]||1888||1958||Biologist|| |- |[[George Vibert Douglas]]||1892||1958||Geologist||Born in Montreal, Canada. Professor of Geology, Dalhousie University (1932-1957) |- |[[James William Slessor Marr|James Marr]]||1902||1965||[[Boy Scout]]||With Mooney was selected from 1,700 Scouts who applied to accompany the expedition |- |Norman MooneyFull name: Norman Erland Mooney||''c''.1904||||[[Boy Scout]]||Left the ship at Madeira after suffering chronic seasickness |- |[[Douglas George Jeffrey]]||1885||1972||Navigator||Had been intended for the original crew on the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition, but when [[World War I|war]] broke out on the eve of ''Endurance'''s departure he felt compelled to stay in England to sign up. |- |EriksenNot in Wild's crew list in his report to the Royal Geographical Society, but mentioned in ''Shackleton's Last Voyage''||||||Harpoon Expert||Returned home when the ''Quest'' put in at [[Rio de Janeiro]] for repairs |- |[[John Charles Bee-Mason]]Also known as John Charles Mason||''c''.1875||1957||Photographer||Left the ship at Madeira after suffering chronic seasickness |- |C. E. Smith||||||2nd Engineer|| |- |Harold Watts||||||Wireless Operator|| |- |G. H. RossProbably George Hamblin Ross||||||Stoker|| |- |S. S. Young||||||Stoker||Joined the expedition in Rio de Janeiro |- |Harold Arthur Argles Listed as James Argyles in Mills, p.340; as Argle and Argles in ''Shackleton's Last Voyage''; as H. J. Argyles in the crew list of Wild's report to the Royal Geographical Society, and as Argles later in the same document.||1899||1929||Stoker||Joined the expedition in Rio de Janeiro. |- |Christopher Naisbitt||||||Cook's assistant||Joined the expedition in Rio de Janeiro |- |Query (Dog)||1920/21He was a puppy when Shackleton brought him on board in early 1921||1922||Mascot||Washed overboard and drowned on June 9, 1922 |- |Questie (Cat)||1921||||Mascot||A kitten presented to the expedition by the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' |} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book|last= Mills|first= Leif|title= Frank Wild|publisher= Caedmon of Whitby|location= Whitby|year= 1999|isbn= 0-905355-48-2}} *{{cite web|author= Wild, Frank|title= Shackleton's Last Voyage: The Story of the ''Quest''|url= https://archive.org/stream/shackletonslastv00wilduoft/shackletonslastv00wilduoft_djvu.txt|publisher= www.archive.org|accessdate= 3 December 2008}} *{{cite journal|journal=The Geographical Journal|title=The Voyage of the ''Quest''|first=Frank|last=Wild|issue=2|date=2 February 1923|pages=73–97|volume=61|doi=10.2307/1781104}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Personnel of the Shackleton-Rowett Expedition}} [[Category:Exploration of Antarctica]] [[Category:United Kingdom and the Antarctic]] [[Category:1921 in Antarctica]] [[Category:Antarctica-related lists]] [[Category:Antarctic expeditions]]

{{Infobox subdivision type | name = Provinces of Cuba
Provincias de Cuba ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]) | alt_name = | map = [[File:CubaSubdivisions.png|300px]] | category = [[Unitary state]] | territory = [[Republic of Cuba]] | start_date = | current_number = 15 Provinces
1 Special Municipality | number_date = | population_range = 84,263 ([[Isla de la Juventud]]) – 2,154,454 ([[La Habana]]) | area_range = {{Convert|281.18|sqmi}} ([[Isla de la Juventud]]) – {{Convert|5951.31|sqmi}} ([[Camagüey Province]]) | government = Single Party Government | subdivision = [[Municipalities of Cuba|Municipality]] }} [[Administrative division|Administratively]], '''[[Cuba]]''' is divided into 15 '''provinces''' and a special [[municipality]] that's not included in any province. The last modification was approved in August 2010 (by the Cuban National Assembly), splitting Havana province into two new provinces: [[Artemisa Province|Artemisa]] (which incorporates the three eastern municipalities of the neighbour [[Pinar del Río]]) and [[Mayabeque Province|Mayabeque]]. The new provinces started functioning from January 1, 2011. Havana City Province ([[Ciudad de La Habana]]) recovered its original name: [[La Habana]] (Havana in [[English language|English]]). == List of provinces == From west to east, Cuba's provinces are: # [[Pinar del Río Province|Pinar del Río]] # [[Artemisa Province|Artemisa]] # [[Havana]] # [[Mayabeque Province|Mayabeque]] # [[Matanzas Province|Matanzas]] # [[Cienfuegos Province|Cienfuegos]] # [[Villa Clara Province|Villa Clara]] # [[Sancti Spíritus Province|Sancti Spíritus]] # [[Ciego de Ávila Province|Ciego de Ávila]] # [[Camagüey Province|Camagüey]] # [[Las Tunas Province|Las Tunas]] # [[Granma Province|Granma]] # [[Holguín Province|Holguín]] # [[Santiago de Cuba Province|Santiago de Cuba]] # [[Guantánamo Province|Guantánamo]] # [[Isla de la Juventud]] is a "special municipality". Isla de la Juventud ("Island of Youth") was known until the 1970s as the ''Isla de Pinos'' ("Isle of Pines"). == History == [[File:Cuba_Map_Colors_ProvinciasRev_wNumbs.jpg|thumb|Cuban Provinces 1879 to 1976]] The provinces were created in 1879 by the Spanish colonial government. From 1879 to 1976, Cuba was divided into 6 provinces, which maintained with little changes the same boundaries and capital cities, although with modifications in official names. These "historical" provinces are the following (from west to east): # Pinar del Río # La Habana, included the city of [[Havana]], current [[Mayabeque Province|Mayabeque]], some municipalities of current [[Artemisa Province]] (prior to 1970: 5 municipalities; from 1970 to 2011, 8 municipalities, including [[Artemisa]] city itself).
The Isle of Pines (currently named "Isle of Youth") was considered a "special municipality" in The Province of La Habana. # Matanzas # Las Villas (before 1940 named "[[Santa Clara Province|Santa Clara]]"), contained the present-day provinces of [[Cienfuegos Province|Cienfuegos]], [[Villa Clara Province|Villa Clara]], [[Sancti Spíritus Province|Sancti Spíritus]], and Southern [[Matanzas]] Province. # Camagüey (before 1899 named "Puerto Príncipe"), contained the present-day provinces of [[Camagüey Province|Camagüey]] and [[Ciego de Ávila Province|Ciego de Ávila]], as well as two municipalities of current [[Las Tunas Province]] (prior to 1970). # [[Oriente Province|Oriente]] (before 1905 named "Santiago de Cuba"), contained the present-day provinces of [[Las Tunas Province|Las Tunas]], [[Granma Province|Granma]], [[Holguín Province|Holguín]], [[Santiago de Cuba Province|Santiago de Cuba]] and [[Guantánamo Province|Guantánamo]] == Demographics == ''Pop. = Population. {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} The '''smoking age''' is the minimum legal age required to purchase or smoke [[tobacco]] products. Most countries have laws that restrict those below a minimum age from legally purchasing tobacco products. == Smoking age laws by region == === Africa === {{Expand list|date=June 2015}} [[File:Verkaufsalter für Tabakwaren in Afrika.svg|thumb|right|'''Minimum age to purchase tobacco in [[Africa]] as of 2015:'''
{{legend|#B200FF|Minimum age is 19}}{{legend|#0026FF|Minimum age is 18}}{{legend|#267F00|Minimum age is 16}}{{legend|#C0C0C0|No minimum age}}]] {| class="wikitable" style="width:75%;" |- ! rowspan=2 style="width:30%;"| Country ! colspan=2 style="width:30%;"| [[De jure]] ! rowspan=2 style="width:40%;"| Notes |- ! style="width:15%;"| Legal age to smoke any tobacco products ! style="width:15%;"| Legal age to buy any tobacco products |- | {{flag|Algeria}} | align=center | None | align=center | 19 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to minors under the age of 19 years.
''(Chapitre IV sur les problèmes de santé l'article 93: "la vente de tabac ou produits du tabac aux mineurs est interdite".)''{{cite web |url=http://www.aps.dz/sante-sciences-tech/11256-le-projet-de-la-loi-relative-%C3%A0-la-sant%C3%A9-interdit-la-vente-du-tabac-et-des-boissons-alcoolis%C3%A9es-aux-mineurs |title=Le projet de la loi relative à la santé interdit la vente du tabac et des boissons alcoolisées aux mineurs |author= |date=16 September 2014 |language=fr |website=aps.dz |page= |publisher=Algérie Presse Service |access-date=23 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Angola}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco to minors under the age of 18.{{cite web|title=Lei n° 1/07 de 14 de Maio 2007 das Actividades Comerciais – Artigo 36 º - q)|url=http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/text.jsp?file_id=220575|publisher=wipo.int|accessdate=30 January 2015}} |- | {{flag|Benin}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Benin/Benin%20-%20Law%20No.%202006-12.pdf |title=Law No. 2006-12 Concerning Regulation of the Production, Commercialization and Consumption of Cigarettes and Other Tobacco Products Article 22: Prohibition |author= |date= |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=6 |publisher=THE NATIONAL ASSEMBLY |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Botswana}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco to minors under the age of 18. Any person who sells, by retail, any tobacco product, shall display clearly, for the public, a notice to the effect that the sale of any tobacco product to a person under the age of 18 years is prohibited.{{cite web|title=Control of Smoking Act, 1992: CHAPTER 65:04 – PART II – 8.|url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Botswana/Botswana%20-%20Control%20of%20Smoking%20Act,%201992%20-%20national.pdf|accessdate=30 January 2015}} |- | {{flag|Burkina Faso}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Burkina%20Faso/Burkina%20Faso%20-%20Law%20No.%20040-2010.pdf |title=Law No. 040-2010/Concerning Tobacco Control in Burkina Faso (as promulgated by Decree N° 2010-823) Article 23 |author= |date=25 November 2011 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=9 |publisher=PRESIDENT OF THE COUNCIL OF MINISTERS |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Burundi}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell cigarettes to anyone under the age of 18. Other tobacco products are not regulated.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Burundi/Burundi%20-%20Decree%20No.%20630%20-%20national.pdf |title=Decree No. 630/3007/CAB/2011 |author= |date=10 October 2011 |language=fr |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Cameroon}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Cape Verde}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Central African Republic}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Chad}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco to a minor. Minors and pregnant women may not smoke in public.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Chad/Chad%20-%20TC%20Law%20No.%20010.pdf |title=Law No. 010/PR/2010 on Tobacco Control |author= |date=10 June 2010 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher=Government of Chad |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Comoros}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | The sale of tobacco products to minors is prohibited. Vendors of tobacco products must visibly and prominently display at their point of sale a notice of prohibition of the sale of tobacco to minors and by minors.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Comoros/Comoros%20-%20Decree%20No.%2011-140%20on%20TC%20Law.pdf |title=Law No. 11-002/AU of 27 March 2011 on Tobacco Control CHAPTER IV.- Article 11 |author= |date=14 July 2011 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher=UNION OF THE COMOROS |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Republic of the Congo}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Congo/Congo%20-%20Law%20No.%2012-2012.pdf |title=Law No. 12-2012 on Tobacco Control |author= |date=4 July 2012 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=1 |publisher=NATIONAL ASSEMBLY AND THE SENATE |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | It is illegal for minors to smoke in public, and for anyone to give or sell tobacco to a minor.
(''ARRETE MINISTERIEL N°1250 Article 1: L'usage, la vente, l'achat et la consommation du tabac, de ses produits et de ses dérivés sont strictement interdits aux mineurs.''){{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Democratic%20Republic%20of%20the%20Congo/Democratic%20Republic%20of%20the%20Congo%20-%20No.%201250%20-%20national.pdf |title=ARRETE MINISTERIEL N°1250 /CAB/MIN/SP/~f.:/A0/2007 DU, /l~./07/2007 PORTANT MESURES APPLICABLES A L'USAGE ET A LA CONSOMMATION DU TABAC ET SES DERIVES Article 1. |author= |date=19 July 2007 |language=fr |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=2 |publisher=LE MINISTRE DE LA SANTE PUBLIQUE |access-date=3 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Djibouti}} | align=center | None | align=center | 16 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to a minor under the age of 16 years. A notice with the sale restrictions has to be placed at point of sale.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Djibouti/Djibouti%20-%20Law%20No.%20175-AN-07%20.pdf |title=Law No. 175-AN-07 on Tobacco Control Article 23 and Article 24 |author= |date=2 December 2007 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=5 |publisher=Government of Djibouti |access-date=6 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Egypt}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 |The sale of tobacco products to persons under the age of 18 is prohibited. |- | {{flag|Equatorial Guinea}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Equatorial%20Guinea/Equatorial%20Guinea%20-%20Decree%20No.%203_1988%20-%20national.pdf |title=Decree No. 3/1988 |author= |date= |language=es |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Eritrea}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Eritrea/Eritrea%20-%20Proc.%20No.%20143_2004%20-%20national.pdf |title=Proclamation No. 143/2004 to Provide for Tobacco Control Article 6. Distribution |author= |date= |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher=Government of Eritrea |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Ethiopia}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | ''"No person may directly or indirectly give, provide or sell any tobacco product to a person under the age of 18."''{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Ethiopia/Ethiopia%20-%20Tobacco%20Ctrl.%20Dir.%20No.%2028_2015%20-%20national.pdf |title=Tobacco Control Directive 17. Protection of minors from tobacco products |author= |date=2015 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher=Ethiopian Food, Medicine and Healthcare Administration and Control Authority |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Gabon}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Gabon/Gabon%20-%202013%20TC%20Law.pdf |title=Law No. 006/2013 on Tobacco Control Article 17 |author= |date= |language=en |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher=Official Journal of the Republic of Gabon |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Gambia}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Ghana}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Ghana/Ghana%20-%20Pub.%20Health%20Act%202012%20-%20national.pdf |title=Public Health Act, 2012 (Act 851) 65. Minimum age restrictions |author= |date=9 October 2012 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=33 |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Guinea-Bissau}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Kenya}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18 years. There is no minimum age to possess tobacco or smoke in public.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Kenya/Kenya%20-%20Tobacco%20Control%20Act%20-%20national.pdf |title=The Tobacco Control Act, 2007 15. Supply to and by young persons. |author= |date=2007 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=12 |publisher=Parliament |access-date=3 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Lesotho}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Liberia}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | It is illegal to sell or supply tobacco to a minor. Minors may not consume tobacco at any public place.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Liberia/Liberia%20-%20Tobacco%20Regs%20%282011%29%20-%20national.pdf |title=The Tobacco Regulations |author= |date=1 September 2011 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=3 |publisher= |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Libya}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is strictly prohibited to sell any tobacco product to a person under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Libya/Libya%20-%20Decision%20No.%20206.pdf |title=Decision No. (206) for 2009 by the General People's Committee Approving Rulings on the Control of Smoking, Tobacco and All Tobacco Products Article (10) |author= |date=2009 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=4 |publisher=General People's Committee |access-date=3 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Madagascar}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Madagascar/Madagascar%20-%20Order%20No.%2018171.pdf |title=Interministerial Order No. 18171/2003 Art. 9 |author= |date=20 January 2004 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=4 |publisher=MINISTRY OF ECONOMY, FINANCE AND BUDGET – MINISTRY OF INDUSTRIALIZATION, TRADE AND PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT – MINISTRY OF HEALTH |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Malawi}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Mali}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Mali/Mali%20-%20Law%20No.%2010-033.pdf |title=Law No. 10-033 of July 12, 2010 on the Sale and Consumption of Tobacco and Tobacco Products Article 8: Access to tobacco products |author= |date=12 July 2010 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=2 |publisher=National Assembly |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Mauritius}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | A person must be 18 years old to purchase or to smoke cigarettes including any tobacco products as is indicated in Public Health ''(Restrictions on Tobacco Products) Regulations 1999, Sec. 2(e)(i))''. |- | {{flag|Morocco}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 16 | |- | {{flag|Mozambique}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Mozambique/Mozambique%20-%20Decree%20No.%2011-2007%20-%20national.pdf |title=Decree No. 11/2007 Artigo 12 |author= |date= |language=pt |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Namibia}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell or supply tobacco to a minor.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Namibia/Namibia%20-%20Tobacco%20Products%20Control%20-%20national.pdf |title=Tobacco Products Control Act, 2010 PART 4 Section 18. |author= |date=14 April 2010 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=15 |publisher=OFFICE OF THE PRIME MINISTER |access-date=3 June 2015}}
''No minimum age prior to 14 April 2010.'' |- | {{flag|Niger}} | align=center | None
18 (to enter smoking room or facility) | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to a minor. (50 states and integral territories) The federal law requires states to have a minimum age of 18 years for sale/purchase of tobacco products (21 U.S.C. § 387f. (3)(a)(ii)). State and local laws may extend this ban and also prohibit supply, possession and consumption to/by person underage, or increase the age beyond 18. However, most states do not directly ban the consumption of tobacco by a minor. The federal law requiring states to have a minimum purchasing age at 18 is enforced by withholding [[FEMA]] disaster and non-disaster grants from states that have purchasing ages under 18, and currently no state falls under that category. {| class="wikitable collapsible" ! Any police-officer in uniform or any other person or class of persons duty authorized by the Government has the power to seize and destroy tobacco products of anyone under the age of 16 years whom he finds smoking in public.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Bangladesh/Bangladesh%20-%20Juvenile%20Smoking%20Act.pdf |title=The Juvenile Smoking Act, 1919 Section 3 and 4 |author= |date=1919 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page= |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Cambodia}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | Any act of selling or distributing all types of tobacco products to persons aged under 18 years or to pregnant women whose pregnancy is obvious or is realized must be punished with six days to one month in prison and a fine of 100,000 riel to 1 million riel.{{cite web |url=https://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/parties-unite-to-pass-strict-tobacco-control-law-81703/ |title=Parties Unite to Pass Strict Tobacco Control Law |author=Hul Reaksmey |date=9 April 2015 |website=cambodiadaily.com |page= |publisher=The Cambodia Daily |access-date=10 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|China}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to minors. ''No age limit prior to 29 December 2006.''{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/China/China%20-%20Law%20on%20the%20Protection%20of%20Minors.pdf |title=Law on Protection of Minors of the People's Republic of China |author= |date=29 December 2006 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=1 |publisher=Seventh National People's Congress |access-date=29 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Hong Kong}} | style="text-align:center;" colspan=2| 18 | It is illegal to sell, give or otherwise furnish tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Hong%20Kong%20%28China%29/Hong%20Kong%20%28China%29%20-%20Smoking%20Ordinance%20-%20national.pdf |title=SMOKING (PUBLIC HEALTH) ORDINANCE PART IVA |author= |date=27 October 2006 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=11 |publisher=Government of Hong Kong |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|India}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell cigarettes or any other tobacco product to a person under the age of 18 years. It is illegal to sell tobacco within a radius of one hundred yards of any educational institution.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/India/India%20-%20COTPA.pdf |title=THE CIGARETTES AND OTHER TOBACCO PRODUCTS (PROHIBITIONOF ADVERTISEMENT AND REGULATION OF TRADE AND COMMERCE, PRODUCTION, SUPPLY AND DISTRIBUTION) ACT, 2003 Section 6 |author= |date=18 May 2003 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=4 |publisher=MINISTRY OF LAW AND JUSTICE |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Indonesia}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell and supply tobacco products to pregnant women or anyone under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Indonesia/Indonesia%20-%20PP%20No.%20109%20of%202012.pdf |title=CONTROL OF MATERIALS THAT CONTAIN ADDICTIVE SUBSTANCES IN TOBACCO PRODUCTS IN THE INTERESTS OF HEALTHPart Three: Distribution Article 25 |author= |date=2012 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=9 |publisher=Government of Indonesia |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Iran}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell and supply tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18 years. Violation will result in confiscation of tobacco from the minor and a fine for the salesperson.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Iran/Iran%20-%20Comp.%20TC%20Act.pdf |title=COMPREHENSIVE ACT ON NATIONAL CONTROL AND CAMPAIGN AGAINST TOBACCO ARTICLE 12 |author= |date=29 October 2005 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=3 |publisher=ISLAMIC CONSULTATIVE ASSEMBLY |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Iraq}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| None | |- | {{flag|Israel}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to a minor.

Retrieved on 29 September 2011. |- | {{flag|Qatar}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell cigarettes or any other tobacco to a person under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Qatar/Qatar%20-%20Law%20No.%2020%20of%202002%20on%20Control%20of%20Tobacco%20and%20its%20Derivatives.pdf |title=Law No. 20 of 2002 on the Control of Tobacco and its Derivatives Article 7 |author= |date= |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=4 |publisher=Shura Council |access-date=2 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Saudi Arabia}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | |- | {{flag|Singapore}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | Singapore takes a very stern view on underage smoking. The smoking age in Singapore is currently 18, increasing to 19 on January 1st 2019, 20 on January 1st 2020 and eventually 21 by January 1st 2021.
It is illegal to sell or give, directly or indirectly any tobacco product to any under-aged person, and anyone caught doing so will be subjected to harsh penalties. Anyone caught selling tobacco products to an under-aged person will be charged in court and can be fined up to 5,000 Singapore dollars for the first offense, and up to $10,000 for the second and subsequent offenses. In addition, the store involved will have the tobacco license suspended for 6 months at the first offense, and permanently revoked for the second offense. However, if the store involved is caught selling to minors in school uniform, or to minors below the age of 12, the tobacco license will be permanently revoked even at its first offense. Anyone caught buying tobacco products for an under-aged person will be charged in court can be fined up to 2,500 Singapore for the first offence, and up to 5,000 for the second and subsequent offences. Anyone caught giving tobacco products to an under-aged person will be charged in court and can be fined up to 500 Singapore dollars for the first offence, and up to 1,000 Singapore dollars for the second and subsequent offences. No minor is allowed to consume or possess any tobacco product in public. Minors caught doing so are usually given a warning or a 30-dollar composition fine. Minors caught four or more times can be charged in court and be fined up to 300 Singapore dollars. {{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Singapore/Singapore%20-%20Control%20of%20Ads%20%26%20Sale%20-%20national.pdf |title=Tobacco (Control of Advertisements and Sale) Act PART III CONTROL '''"'''''(…)any person who provides a tobacco product to a minor is guilty of offense and in any case of his/her conviction, he/she shall be subject to a penalty not exceeding one thousand pounds or to incarceration not exceeding six months and/or to both penalties.'''''"'''{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Cyprus/Cyprus%20-%20Reduction%20of%20Smoking.pdf |title=LAW THAT PROVIDES FOR MEASURES FOR THE REDUCTION OF SMOKING 3.- Prohibition to provide tobacco to minors. |author= |date=14 June 2002 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=3 |publisher=Cyprus Legal Portal |access-date=1 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Czech Republic}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | Selling tobacco products to anyone under 18 is prohibited. Sale of tobacco products and tobacco through vending machines is permitted if the tobacco purchase age is not violated. The seller shall place a clearly visible notice displaying the sale restrictions of tobacco to person under the age of 18. A person selling tobacco must be 18 years or older, unless the minor is preparing for a future career in the hotel or tourism industry, as a cook-waiter or salesman. However, it is very easy to get tobacco products for minors as many sellers don't check the age.{{cite web |url= |title=CÁST první Ochrana pred škodami pusobenými tabákovými výrobky, alkoholem a JINÝMI návykovými látkami Zákazy a omezení prodeje tabákových výrobku a povinnosti osob prodávajících tabákové výrobky: § 4, § 6, § 7 |author= |date= |language=cs|websiteobecnipolicie.cz= |page= |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}}
''The minimum age was 16 years prior to 2 September 1999.''{{cite web |url=http://www.esipa.cz/sbirka/SBSRV.DLL/sb?DR=SB&CP=1999s190 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080215000622/http://www.esipa.cz/sbirka/sbsrv.dll/sb?DR=SB&CP=1999s190 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 February 2008 |title=190/1999 Sb.Zákon, kterým se mění zákon č. 37/1989 Sb., o ochraně před alkoholismem a jinými toxikomaniemi, ve znění pozdějších předpisů |author= |date=2 September 1999 |language=cs |website=esipa.cz |page= |publisher=Parliament of the Czech Republic |access-date=29 May 2015 }} |- | {{flag|Denmark}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | ''The minimum age was 16 years prior to 1 September 2008.''{{cite web |url=https://www.retsinformation.dk/Forms/r0710.aspx?id=121328 |title=LBK nr 1020 af 21/10/2008 Gældende Bekendtgørelse af lov om forbud mod salg af tobak til personer under 18 år og salg af alkohol til personer under 16 år: 1. § 1 |author= |date= |language=Danish|website=retsinformation.dk |page= |publisher= |access-date=25 May 2015}} |- | {{flag|Estonia}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | The minimum age to purchase tobacco products or to smoke in public is set at 18. Minors may not be in possession of, or handle tobacco products.{{cite web |url=http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Estonia/Estonia%20-%20Tobacco%20Act.pdf |title=Tobacco Act § 27., § 28. |author= |date=4 May 2005 |website=tobaccocontrollaws.org |page=15 |publisher= |access-date=29 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150613153140/http://www.tobaccocontrollaws.org/files/live/Estonia/Estonia%20-%20Tobacco%20Act.pdf |archivedate=13 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} |- | {{flag|Finland}} | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | Prior to October 2010 it was not illegal for minors to smoke in public.

It is illegal to sell tobacco to anyone under the age of 18.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2007/767/contents/made |title=The Children and Young Persons (Sale of Tobacco etc.) Order 2007 2. Substitution of references to age in sections 7 and 102 of the 1933 Act |author= |date=2007 |website=legislation.gov.uk |page=1 |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom |access-date=1 June 2015}} The minimum age to smoke in public is 16 and authorities have the duty to seize any tobacco or cigarette papers in the possession of any person apparently under the age of 16.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Geo5/23-24/12/section/7 |title=Children and Young Persons Act 1933 c. 12 Part I – Offences – Section 7 (3) |author= |date=1933 |website=legislation.gov.uk |page=1 |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom |access-date=1 June 2015}}
''Minimum age to purchase was 16 from 1908 to 1 October 2007.'' ''No minimum age prior to 1908.'' |- | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | '''{{flag|Scotland}}:'''
A person who sells a tobacco product or cigarette papers to a person under the age of 18 commits an offence. Any person under the age of 18 who buys or attempts to buy a tobacco product or cigarette papers commits an offence as well as an adult who knowlingly buys a tobacco product or cigarette papers on behalf of a person under the age of 18.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/asp/2010/3/part/1/chapter/1/crossheading/sale-and-purchase-of-tobacco-products |title=Tobacco and Primary Medical Services (Scotland) Act 2010 Chapter 1 – Sale and purchase of tobacco products |author= |date=2010 |website=legislation.gov.uk |page= |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom |access-date=10 June 2015}} Any constable who has reasonable grounds for suspecting that a person in a public place is under the age of 18, and in possession of a tobacco product or cigarette papers may require the person to surrender the tobacco product.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/asp/2010/3/section/7 |title=Tobacco and Primary Medical Services (Scotland) Act 2010 Chapter 1 – Miscellaneous |author= |date=2010 |website=legislation.gov.uk |page= |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom |access-date=10 June 2015}}
''Minimum age was 16 prior to 30 September 2007.'' |- | colspan=2 style="text-align:center;"| 18 | '''[[Northern Ireland]]:'''
A person who sells to a person under the age of 18 any tobacco or cigarette papers, whether for his or her own use or not, shall be guilty of an offence. A member of the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] may seize any tobacco or cigarette papers in the possession of any person apparently under the age of 18 whom he or she finds smoking in any street or public place.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/nisi/1978/1907/part/II |title=Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1978 PART II – SALE OF TOBACCO, ETC. TO PERSONS APPARENTLY UNDER 18 |author= |date=1978 |website=legislation.gov.uk |page= |publisher=Government of the United Kingdom |access-date=10 June 2015}}
''Minimum age was 16 prior to 1 September 2008.'' |- |} {{notelist}} === Oceania === {{Expand list|date=June 2015}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:75%;" |- ! rowspan=2 style="width:30%;"| Country ! colspan=2 style="width:30%;"| [[De jure]] ! rowspan=2 style="width:40%;"| Notes |- ! style="width:15%;"| Smoking age ! style="width:15%;"| Purchase age |- | colspan=4 |{{flag|Australia}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" ! Regulations by state/territory: |- |style="background:#F2F2F2;text-align:center;width:20%;"|'''Province/territory''' |style="background:#F2F2F2;text-align:center;width:15%;"|'''Smoking age''' |style="background:#F2F2F2;text-align:center;width:15%;"|'''Purchase age''' |style="background:#F2F2F2;text-align:center;width:50%;"|'''Notes''' |- | {{flag|Australian Capital Territory}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell tobacco products to a person under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www5.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/act/consol_act/ta192773/s14.html |title=TOBACCO ACT 1927 SECT 14 Supply of smoking product to under 18 year olds |author= |date=1927 |website=austlii.edu.au |page= |publisher=AustLII |access-date=10 June 2015}} Further it is illegal to buy a tobacco product for a minor.{{cite web |url=http://www5.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/act/consol_act/ta192773/s15.html |title= TOBACCO ACT 1927 SECT 15 Purchase of smoking products for use by under 18 year olds |author= |date=1927 |website=austlii.edu.au |page= |publisher=AustLII |access-date=10 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|New South Wales}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell any tobacco or non-tobacco smoking product to a person who is under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/#/view/act/2008/94/part4/div1 |title=TOBACCO ACT 1927 - Division 1 Juvenile smoking |website=legislation.nsw.gov.au}} |- | {{flag|Northern Territory}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell any tobacco product to a minor or on behalf of a minors. It is illegal to smoke in a vehicle with a person under the age of 18 years present.{{cite web |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nt/consol_act/tca163/s42.html |title=TOBACCO CONTROL ACT SECT 42 Sale to children prohibited |author= |date= |website=austlii.edu.au |page= |publisher=AustLII |access-date=10 June 2015}}{{cite web |url= |title=TOBACCO CONTROL ACT SECT 43 Supply to, or purchase for, children prohibited |author= |date= |website=austlii.edu.au |page= |publisher=AustLII |access-date=10 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Queensland}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal for an adult to supply a tobacco product to a person under the age of 18 years; however, a responsible adult for a child does not commit an offence by supplying a smoking product to the child.{{cite web |url=https://www.legislation.qld.gov.au/LEGISLTN/CURRENT/T/TobacoOSmPrA98.pdf |title=Tobacco and Other Smoking Products Act 1998 |author= |date=1998 |website=legislation.qld.gov.au |page= |publisher= |access-date=10 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|South Australia}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is an offence to supply any tobacco product to a person under the age of 18 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/A/TOBACCO%20PRODUCTS%20REGULATION%20ACT%201997/CURRENT/1997.26.UN.PDF |title=Tobacco Products Regulation Act 1997 |author= |date= |website=legislation.sa.gov.au |page=11 |publisher= |access-date=10 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150613020807/http://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/A/TOBACCO%20PRODUCTS%20REGULATION%20ACT%201997/CURRENT/1997.26.UN.PDF |archivedate=13 June 2015 |df=dmy-all }} |- | {{flag|Tasmania}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell or supply tobacco to a person under the age of 18 years.
''Minimum age was 16 prior to 1 January 1997.''{{cite web |url=http://www.dhhs.tas.gov.au/publichealth/tobacco_control/tobacco_control_laws/smoke-free/history |title=History of tobacco laws in Tasmania |author= |date= |website=dhhs.tas.gov.au |page= |publisher=Department of Health and Human Services |access-date=10 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Victoria}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to supply tobacco to a minor. Smoking in a vehicle with a person under 18 present is an offence.{{cite web |url=http://www5.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/vic/consol_act/ta198773/s12.html |title=TOBACCO ACT 1987 SECT 12 Supplying tobacco to person under 18 years |author= |date=1987 |website=austlii.edu.au |page= |publisher=AustLII |access-date=10 June 2015}} |- | {{flag|Western Australia}} | align=center | None | align=center | 18 | It is illegal to sell, deliver or supply tobacco or smoking implement to a minor. {{Infobox Scottish island |coordinates = {{coord|57.88|-8.49|display=inline}} |location_map=Scotland Outer Hebrides |caption=Stac an Armin shown within the Outer Hebrides |GridReference=NA151064 |official_name=Stac an Armin |celtic name=Stac an Àrmainn |norse name= |meaning of name=(Gaelic) "stack of the warrior" |area= {{convert|9.9|ha|acre|0|abbr=on}} |area rank= |highest elevation= {{convert|196|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |Population=0 |population rank= |main settlement= |island group=[[St Kilda, Scotland|St Kilda]] |local authority=[[Outer Hebrides]] |references=<ref>2001 UK Census per [[List of islands of Scotland]].</ref><ref name=Smith>{{Haswell-Smith}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/ Ordnance Survey].</ref> }}
'''Stac an Armin''' ([[Scottish Gaelic Language|Scottish Gaelic]]: ''Stac an Àrmainn''), based on the proper [[Scottish Gaelic]] spelling (formerly ''àrmuinn''), is a [[sea stack]] in the [[St Kilda, Scotland|St Kilda]] [[archipelago]]. It is 196 metres (643 ft.) tall, qualifying it as a [[Marilyn (hill)|Marilyn]].<ref name="mcos">{{cite web| url = http://www.mountaineering-scotland.org.uk/nl/48c.html| title = St Kilda Management Plan Review| work = The Scottish Mountaineer| publisher = [[Mountaineering Council of Scotland]]| date = 2002| accessdate = 2009-02-05}}</ref> It is the highest sea stack in Scotland and the British Isles.<ref>{{cite news| title = Corrections and clarifications| work = [[The Guardian]]| date =16 April 2007| url = https://www.theguardian.com/news/2007/apr/16/leadersandreply.mainsection2| accessdate = 2009-02-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last = Dawson| first = Alan| title = Relative Hills of Britain| publisher = Cicerone Press| year= 1992| location = | page = 109| url = https://books.google.com/?id=aZZCW040bSAC| isbn = 978-1-85284-068-6}}</ref><ref>The National Trust for Scotland has 191 m. {{cite web| url = http://www.kilda.org.uk/frame5.htm| title = St Kilda: Fascinating Facts| website = St Kilda - National Trust for Scotland World Heritage Site| publisher = [[National Trust for Scotland]]| accessdate = 2009-02-05}}</ref>
The name Stac an Armin means stack of the soldier/warrior, and evidence remains showing it was used by people living nearby as a hunting grounds. It is not believed to have been inhabited year round, but has hosted some (involuntary) extended stays. Climbing the rocks was once done to collect eggs and has continued in the form of recreational sport. The island was once home to the now extinct [[great auk]], and rules exist to protect the bird habitats and breeding grounds.
Stac an Armin is 400 metres (¼ mi) north of [[Boreray, St Kilda|Boreray]] and near the 172-metre-high (564 ft) [[Stac Lee]]. Stac an Armin is separated from Boreray by a channel "so littered with rocks" that it should not be sailed,<ref>{{cite book| last = Haswell-Smith| first = Hamish| title = An Island Odyssey: Among the Scottish Isles in the Wake of Martin Martin| publisher = Canongate U.S.| date = 2000| location = | page = 87| url = https://books.google.com/?id=ShLgV4xwBEEC| isbn = 978-1-84195-082-2}}</ref> though sailors write passionately about the views.<ref>{{cite book| last = Nicolson| first = Adam| title = Seamanship: A Voyage Along the Wild Coasts of the British Isles| publisher = HarperCollins| date = 2005| location = | page = 134| url = https://books.google.com/?id=wbw1UN6EiSgC| isbn = 978-0-06-075342-9}}</ref>
[[File:Stac an Armin and Boreray.jpg|thumb|left|Stac an Armin with [[Boreray, St Kilda|Boreray]] to the left and [[Stac Lee]] beyond at right]]
==History and people== The first written account of the island was [[Martin Martin]]'s description in the early 18th century. Martin wrote about the island after the Scottish writer had visited St Kilda in 1697 and included a few anecdotes about the stack in his ''A Description of the Western Isles of Scotland'' published in 1703. It was the first comprehensive book on the [[archipelago]], to which was appended "A Late Voyage to St Kilda". Martin calls the island "Stack-Narmin."<ref name="martin">"A Late Voyage to St. Kilda," chapter 2, in {{cite book| last = Martin| first = Martin| editor = Donald J. Macleod| title = A Description of the Western Islands of Scotland (circa 1695)| publisher = | location = | pages = | url = http://www.appins.org/martin.htm| isbn = | deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070313003106/http://www.appins.org/martin.htm| archivedate = 2007-03-13| df = }}</ref>
It was never inhabited full-time, but hunting its bird population helped sustain the way of life of the population of St Kilda, as evidenced by the buildings they left behind. There are no fewer than 78 storage [[St Kilda, Scotland#Prehistoric buildings|cleitean]] on Stac an Armin and a small [[bothy]], built by the St Kildans. Martin describes these cleitean as "pyramids" and wrote they were used to "preserve and dry" birds, especially the "solan goose" ([[northern gannet]]). Martin observed one harvest that brought in 800 birds.<ref name="martin"/> In addition to the geese, the islanders used Stac an Armin for harvesting [[great auk]]s, [[gannet]]s, and [[puffin]]s, as well as their eggs.<ref>{{cite news | last = Black | first = Clair | title = The Ballad of St Kilda | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[The Scotsman]] | date = 2009-01-24 | url = http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/features/The-ballad-of-St-Kilda.4896756.jp | accessdate = 2009-02-05}}</ref> The numerous birds that lived on the island were an important source of sustenance for the people of St Kilda.<ref>{{cite news | last = Williams | first = Huw | title = Islands at the Edge of the World | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 2002-07-18 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/2134537.stm | accessdate = 2009-02-05}}</ref>
[[File:Boreray and the Stacs.jpg|thumb|left|[[Boreray, St Kilda|Boreray]] with Stac an Armin (left) and [[Stac Lee]] (right)]] The longest recorded period anyone ever spent on the island was about nine months. Three men and eight boys from [[Hirta]] were marooned here from about 15 August 1727 until 13 May 1728. As luck would have it, Hirta suffered a [[smallpox]] outbreak while the eleven were on the stack, and thus the islanders were unable to man a boat and retrieve them until the next year.<ref>{{cite book | last = Rackwitz | first = Martin | authorlink = | title = Travels to Terra Incognita: The Scottish Highlands and Hebrides in Early Modern Travellers' Accounts C. 1600 to 1800 | publisher = Waxmann Verlag | date = 2007 | location = | page = 352 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-3-8309-1699-4}}</ref> Such temporary accidental occupation of the island may have been a regular event, since Martin Martin also relates, in an anecdote in ''A Description of the Western Islands of Scotland'', how a group of some twenty men were stranded on the island for a couple of days after the rope that held their boat broke. They survived by fishing, and communicated to their wives that they were alive and well by lighting "as many fires on the top of an eminence as there were men in number." Martin adds, curiously, that the wives were so overjoyed that they managed to produce a record harvest of corn that year.<ref>Martin, A Description of the Western Islands of Scotland.</ref>
The archipelago as a whole was [[St Kilda, Scotland#Evacuation|evacuated in 1930]], and bequeathed to the [[National Trust for Scotland]] in 1957. Hunting birds is no longer allowed, and the stack is visited only occasionally by scientists, journalists and climbers.
==The last great auk in Britain== [[File:greatauk-london.jpg|thumb|right|Mounted great auk, [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]], London]]
On Stac an Armin, in July, 1840, the last [[great auk]] (''Pinguinus impennis'') seen in Britain<ref>Rackwitz, ''Travels to Terra Incognito'', 347.</ref> was caught and killed. A then 75-yr. old inhabitant of St Kilda told Henry Evans, a frequent visitor to the archipelago, that he and his father-in-law with another man had caught a "garefowl," noticing its little wings and the large white spot on its head. They tied it up and kept it alive for three days, and then killed it by beating it with a stick, apparently because they believed it to be a witch.<ref>{{cite book | last = Gaskell | first = Jeremy | authorlink = | title = Who Killed the Great Auk? | publisher = Oxford UP | date = 2000 | location = | page = 142 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=tsUzeXV_7jcC | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-19-856478-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Fuller | first = Errol | authorlink = | title = The Great Auk: The Extinction of the Original Penguin | publisher = Bunker Hill Publishing | date = 2003 | location = | page = 34 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=35rGM50pAoAC | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-1-59373-003-1}}</ref> The last known specimens in the world were killed a few years later either in [[Eldey]], [[Iceland]], or off [[Colony of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]].
==Climbing the stack== Native St Kildans have climbed Stac an Armin and other cliffs in St Kilda for centuries in order to harvest birds and eggs; they climbed [[Alpine style|alpine-style]], barefoot or in thick socks, using ropes pleated of horse hair.<ref name="plan102">{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008 | publisher = [[National Trust for Scotland]] | date = 2003 | location = | page = 102 | url = http://www.kilda.org.uk/StKildaManagementPlan.pdf | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> Modern [[mountaineering|ascents]] are few; some may have been done illegally. Mountaindays.net has no routes, information, or comments;<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Stac an Armin| work =| publisher =Mountaindays.net| date =2008| url =http://www.mountaindays.net/mountains/peak.php?defn=0&area=130&peak=1639| format =| doi =| accessdate =2009-02-06| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110719132518/http://www.mountaindays.net/mountains/peak.php?defn=0&area=130&peak=1639| archivedate =2011-07-19| df =}}</ref> however, chatter among online groups suggests attempts are made.<ref>See, for instance, Alan Dawson, "St Kilda (25)": "I have spoken to four people who have been there and who between them have climbed all the St Kilda Marilyns." {{cite journal| last =Dawson| first =Alan| authorlink =| title =St Kilda (25)| journal =MARHOFN: the Newsletter for Marilyn Baggers| volume =| issue =| pages =| publisher =Marilyn Hall of Fame News| location =| date =May 2001| url =http://www.rhb.org.uk/marhofn/marhofn58/islandhoping.htm| issn =| doi =| id =| accessdate =2009-02-06| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090109141512/http://www.rhb.org.uk/marhofn/marhofn58/islandhoping.htm| archivedate =2009-01-09| df =}}</ref> The summit of Stac an Armin was reached by a party of 11 [[Marilyn (hill)|Marilyn]] [[peak bagging|baggers]] on 13 October 2014.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-29627193 BBC News]</ref> Prior to that, the only verifiable modern ascent happened in 1969, when a group which included [[Richard Balharry MBE|Dick Balharry]] and [[John Morton Boyd]] made a number of ascents in the archipelago, which included climbing Stac an Armin.<ref name="plan102"/>
Climbing Stac an Armin (and [[Stac Lee]]), though attractive ("St Kilda presents some of the most challenging climbing in Britain"<ref name="mcos"/>) is complicated by a number of factors. The climb of Stac an Armin itself is described as "little easier than Stac Lee," but the topography makes it a "major expedition" and "the weather can make nonsense of any landing plans."<ref>Alan Dawson, "St Kilda (25)"</ref> The stack is accessible only with difficulty;<ref>"Landing on Stac an Armin is the difficulty, in this case, as the climb itself is reported to be straightforward." ''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 102.</ref><ref>"I doubt if many in the Marhofn 1000-up club will ever climb Stac an Armin or Stac Lee, unless helicopter-assisted." {{cite journal| last =Brown| first =Hamish| authorlink =| title =Letter to the Editor| journal =The Angry Corrie: Scotland's Heritage Hillzine| volume =55| issue =| pages =| publisher =| location =| date =Oct–Nov 2002| url =http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tac/tac55/letteryo.htm| issn =| doi =| id =| accessdate =2009-02-06| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120204075117/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/tac/tac55/letteryo.htm| archivedate =2012-02-04| df =}}</ref> more importantly, since the entire archipelago is both a [[National Nature Reserves in Scotland|National Nature Reserve]] and a [[World Heritage Site]] (principally for the cliffs and seabird colonies<ref>''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 10. See also p. 66, "It was placed on the World Heritage List in 1986 for its natural characteristics only."</ref>) managed by [[Scottish Natural Heritage]] (SNH), climbing is strictly regulated since it potentially disturbs the natural and cultural heritage and particularly the rich birdlife; according to the 2003 Management Plan, "For natural heritage interests, natural processes will normally be allowed to continue without intervention."<ref>''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 21.</ref>
[[File:St Kilda map.png|thumb|left|The St Kilda archipelago]] The 2003 Management Plan is quite specific about the dangers of climbing in St Kilda: the object of prescription 21.5 is to "Ensure that breeding seabirds are not disturbed by climbing on the cliffs,"<ref>''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 41.</ref> though the Plan suggests the allowance of climbing the cliffs under strictly monitored circumstances.<ref>"St Kilda’s sea cliffs are the highest in the UK and thus offer an attractive challenge to modern day climbers. However, climbing on the sea stacs and cliffs causes disturbance to nesting seabirds and for that reason special permission is required from the Trust and SNH under the terms of the St Kilda bylaws." ''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 45.</ref> Prescription 26.4 states that a policy that satisfies climbers and does not violate the Trust's mission is to be developed.<ref>"Develop a policy on climbing on St Kilda that ensures rock climbing does not in any way interfere with breeding seabirds, vegetated sea cliffs or wild land quality." ''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 45.</ref> The Trust's strict but preliminary position on climbing was formalized quite explicitly: {{quote|Given the difficulty of the climbs, the lack of any rescue or medical facilities on St Kilda and the risk of disturbance to nesting bird on the cliffs, climbing on St Kilda is not permitted without the express permission of the Trust. This is stated formally under the St Kilda Bylaws (No 10).<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = The St Kilda Byelaws | work = St Kilda – National Trust for Scotland World Heritage Site | publisher = [[National Trust for Scotland]] | url = http://www.kilda.org.uk/frame17.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2009-02-06}}</ref> As part of the process of implementing this Management Plan, the Trust will liaise with SNH and the [[Mountaineering Council of Scotland]] to review whether any change is merited to this position.<ref>''St Kilda Management Plan 2003–2008'', 103.</ref>}}
The Mountaineering Council of Scotland, in a review of the plan, "recommends that the NTS celebrate the historical importance and the cultural heritage of the climbing on the Islands of St Kilda."<ref name="mcos"/>
